The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

div.p: A Bold Stroke for a WIFE: A COMEDY; As it is Acted at the THEATRE ROYAL IN LINCOLN'S-INN-FIELDS.
By the Author of the BUSIE-BODY and the GAMESTER.
LONDON: Printed for W. MERES and F. CLAY, without Temple-Bar. MDCCXXIV. [Price One Shilling.]

div.head: To His Grace PHILIP, DUKE and MARQUIS of WHARTON, &c.
div.p:
IT has ever been the Cuſtom of Poets to ſhelter Productions of this Nature under the Patronage of the brighteſt Men of their Time; and 'tis obſerv'd, that the Muſes always met the kindeſt Reception from Perſons of the greateſt Merit. The World will do me Juſtice as to the Choice of my Patron, but will, I fear,
blame my raſh Attempt, in daring to Addreſs Your Grace, and offer at a Work too difficult for our ableſt Pens, viz. an Encomium on Your Grace: I have no Plea againſt ſuch juſt Reflections, but the Diſadvantage of Education, and the Privilege of my Sex.

If Your Grace diſcovers a Genius ſo ſurpriſing in this Dawn of Life, what muſt your riper Years produce? Your Grace has already been diſtinguiſh'd in a moſt peculiar Manner, being the firſt Young Nobleman that ever was admitted into a Houſe of Peers before he reached the Age of One and Twenty: But Your Grace's Judgment and Eloquence ſoon convinced that Auguſt Aſſembly, that the excelling Gifts of Nature ought not to be confin'd to Time. We hope the Example which Ireland has ſet, will ſhortly be followed by an Engliſh Houſe of Lords, and Your Grace made a Member of that Body, to which You will be ſo Conſpicuous an Ornament.

Your good Senſe, and real Love for your Country, taught Your Grace to perſevere in the Principles of your Glorious
Anceſtors, by adhering to the Defender of our Religion and Laws: and the penetrating Wiſdom of Your Royal Maſter, ſaw you merited your Honours ere he conferr'd them. It is one of the greateſt Glories of a Monarch, to diſtinguiſh where to beſtow his Favours; and the World muſt do ours Juſtice, by owning Your Grace's Titles moſt deſervedly worn.

It is with the greateſt Pleaſure imaginable the Friends of Liberty ſee You purſuing the Steps of Your Noble Father: Your Courteous, Affable Temper, free from Pride and Oſtentation, makes Your Name ador'd in the Country, and enables Your Grace to carry what Point You pleaſe. The late Lord Wharton will be ſtill remember'd by every Lover of his Country, which never felt a greater Shock than what his Death occaſion'd: Their Grief had been inconſolable, if Heaven, out of its wonted Beneficence to this Favourite Iſle, had not tranſmitted all his ſhining Qualities to you, and Phenix like, raiſed up one Patriot out of the Aſhes of another.

That Your Grace has a high Eſteem for Learning, particularly appears by the large Progreſs you have made therein: and your Love for the Muſes ſhews a Sweetneſs of Temper, and Generous Humanity, peculiar to the Greatneſs of Your Soul; for ſuch Virtues reign not in the Breaſt of every Man of Quality.

Defer no longer then, my Lord, to charm the World with the Beauty of your Numbers, and ſhew the Poet, as you have done the Orator; convince our unthinking Britous, by what vile Arts France loſt her Liberty; and teach 'em to avoid their own Misfortunes, as well as to weep over Henry IV. who (if it were poſſible for him to know) would forgive the bold Aſſaſſin's Hand, for the Honour of having his Fall celebrated by Your Grace's Pen.

To be diſtinguiſh'd by Perſons of Your Grace's Character, is not only the higheſt Ambition, but the greateſt Reputation to an Author; and it is not the leaſt of my Vanities, to have it known to the Publick I had Your Grace's Leave to prefix Your Name to this Comedy.

I wiſh I were capable to cloath the following Scenes in ſuch a Dreſs, as might be worthy to appear before Your Grace, and draw Your Attention as much as Your Grace's admirable Qualifications do that of all Mankind; but the Muſes, like moſt Females, are leaſt liberal to their own Sex.

All I dare ſay in Favour of this Piece is, that the Plot is entirely New, and the Incidents wholly owing to my own Invention; not borrow'd from our own, or tranſlated from the Works of any Foreign Poet; ſo that they have at leaſt the Charm of Novelty to recommend 'em: If they are ſo lucky in ſome leiſure Hour to give Your Grace the Leaſt Diverſion, they will anſwer the utmoſt Ambition of, my Lord,

closer.signed: Your GRACE's moſt Obedient, Moſt Devoted, and Moſt Humble Servant, SUSANNA CENT-LIVRE.

div.head: RROLOGUE,
div.l: TO-Night we come upon a bold Deſign,
To try to pleaſe without one borrow'd Line:
Our Plot is new, and regularly clear,
And not one ſingle Tittle from Moliere:
O'er bury'd Poets we with Caution tread,
And Pariſh Sextons leave to rob the Dead.
For you, bright Britiſh Fair, in hopes to charm ye,
We bring To-night a Lover from the Army:
You know the Soldiers have the ſtrangeſt Arts,
Such a Proportion of prevailing Parts,
You'd think that they rid Poſt to Womens Hearts.
I wonder whence they draw their bold Pretence;
We do not chuſe them ſure for our Defence:
That Plea is both impolitick and wrong,
And only ſuits ſuch Dames as want a Tongue.
Is it their Eloquence and fine Addreſs?
The Softneſs of their Language?—Nothing leſs.
Is it their Courage, that they bravely dare
To ſtorm the Sex at once?—Egad, 'tis there:
They act by us as in the rough Campaign,
Unmindful of Repulſes, charge again;
They Mine and Countermine, reſolv'd to win,
And, if a Breach is made—they will come in.
You'll think, by what we have of Soldiers ſaid,
Our Female Wit was in the Service bred;
But ſhe is to the hardy Toil a Stranger,
She loves the Cloth indeed, but hates the Danger;
Yet to this Circle of the Brave and Gay,
She bid me for her good Intentions ſay,
She hopes you'll not reduce her to Half-Pay.
As for our Play, 'tis Engliſh Humour all;
Then will you let our Manufacture fall?
Would you the Honour of our Nation raiſe,
Keep Engliſh Credit up, and Engliſh Plays.

row.cell: Sir Philip Modelove, an Old Beau,
Periwinkle, a kind of a ſilly Virtuoſo,
Colonel Fainwell, in Love with Mrs. Lovely.
Mrs. Lovely, a Fortune of Thirty Thouſand Pound,
Mrs. Prim, Wife to Prim the Hofier,

body.head: A Bold Stroke for a WIFE.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I. SCENE a Tavern.
div.stage: Colonel Fainwell and Freeman over a Bottle.

sp.speaker: FREEMAN.
sp.p: COME, Colonel, His Majeſty's Health—You are as melancholly as if you were in Love; I wiſh ſome of the Beauties at Bath ha'n't ſnapt your Heart.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why faith, Freeman, there is ſomething in't; I have ſeen a Lady at Bath, who has kindled ſuch a Flame in me, that all the Waters there can't quench.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Women, like ſome poiſonous Animals, carry their Antidote about 'em:—Is ſhe not to be had, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That's a difficult Queſtion to anſwer; however, I reſolve to try: Perhaps you may be able to ſerve me; you Merchants know one another—The Lady told me herſelf ſhe was under the Charge of four Perſons.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Odſo! 'tis Mrs. Ann Lovely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The ſame; do you know her?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Know her! Ay—Faith, Colonel, your Condition is more deſperate than you imagine; why ſhe is the Talk and Pity of the whole Town; and it is the Opinion of the Learned, that ſhe muſt die a Maid.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Say you ſo? That's ſomewhat odd, in this charitable City—She's a Woman, I hope.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: For ought I know; but it had been as well for her, had Nature made her any other Part of the Creation. The Man which keeps this Houſe, ſerv'd her Father; he is a very honeſt Fellow, and may be of uſe to you; we'll ſend for him to take a Glaſs with us; he'll give you the whole Hiſtory, and 'tis worth your hearing.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But may one truſt him?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: With your Life; I have Obligations enough upon him, to make him do any thing; I ſerve him with Wine. [Knocks.]

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, I know him pretty well my ſelf; I once us'd to frequent a Club that was kept here.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Gentlemen, d'you call?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, ſend up your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Do you know any of this Lady's Guardians, Freeman?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes, I know two of them very well.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Here comes one will give you an Account of them all—Mr. Sackbut, we ſent for you to take a Glaſs with us. 'Tis a Maxim among the Friends of the Bottle, that as long as the Maſter is in Company one may be ſure of good Wine.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Sir, you ſhall be ſure to have as good Wine as you ſend in—Colonel, your moſt humble Servant; you are welcome to Town.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I thank you, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: I am as glad to ſee you, as I ſhould a Hundred Tun of French Claret Cuſtom-free—my Service to you, Sir. [Drinks.] You don't look ſo merry as you us'd to do; are you not well, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: He has got a Woman in his Head, Landlord, can you help him?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: If 'tis in my Power, I ſhan't ſcruple to ſerve my Friend.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Tis one Perquiſite of your Calling.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Ay, at t'other End of the Town, where you Officers uſe, Women are good Forcers of Trade; a wellcuſtom'd Houſe, a handſome Bar-keeper, with clean obliging Drawers, ſoon get the Maſter an Eſtate; but our Citizens ſeldom do any thing but cheat within the Walls—But as to the Lady, Colonel; point you at Particulars, or have you a good Champagne Stomack? Are you in full Pay, or reduc'd, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Reduc'd, reduc'd, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: To the miſerable Condition of a Lover!

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Piſh! That's preferrable to Half-pay; a Woman's Reſolution may break before the Peace; puſh her home, Colonel, there's no parlying with that Sex.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Were the Lady her own Miſtreſs, I have ſome Reaſons to believe I ſhould ſoon command in Chief.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You know Mrs. Lovely, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Know her! Ay, poor Nancy; I have carried her to School many a froſty Morning. Alas, if ſhe's the Woman, I pity you, Colonel: Her Father, my old Maſter, was the moſt whimſical, out-of-the-way temper'd Man, I ever heard of, as you will gueſs by his laſt Will and Teſtament—This was his only Child: I have heard him wiſh her dead a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: He hated Poſterity, you muſt know, and wiſh'd the World were to expire with himſelf—He uſed to ſwear, if ſhe had been a Boy, he would have qualify'd him for the Opera.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis a very unnatural Reſolution in a Father.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: He dy'd worth Thirty thouſand Pounds, which he left to this Daughter, provided ſhe married with the Conſent of her Guardians: But that ſhe might be ſure never to do ſo, he left her in the Care of four Men, as oppoſite to each other as Light and Darkneſs: Each has his quarterly Rule, and three Months in a Year ſhe is oblig'd to be ſubject to each of their Humours, and they are pretty different, I aſſure you—She is juſt come from Bath.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Twas there I ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, the laſt Quarter was her Beau Guardian's—She appears in all publick Places during his Reign.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She viſited a Lady who boarded in the ſame Houſe with me: I lik'd her Perſon, and found an Opportunity to tell her ſo: She reply'd, ſhe had no Objection to mine; but if I could not reconcile Contradictions, I muſt not think of her, for that ſhe was condemned to the Caprice of four Perſons, who never yet agreed in any one thing, and ſhe was oblig'd to pleaſe them all.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: 'Tis moſt true, Sir; I'll give you a ſhort Deſcription of the Men, and leave you to judge of the poor Lady's Condition. One is a kind of a Virtuoſo, a ſilly, half-witted Fellow, but poſitive and ſurly; fond of nothing but what is Antique and Foreign, and wears his Cloaths of the Faſhion of the laſt Century; doats upon Travellers, and believes Sir John Mandiville more than the Bible.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That muſt be a rare old Fellow!

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Another is a Change-Broker; a Fellow that will out-lie the Devil for the Advantage of Stock, and cheat his Father that got him in a Bargain: He is a great Stickler for Trade and hates every thing that wears a Sword.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: He is a great Admirer of the Dutch Management, and ſwears they underſtand Trade better than any Nation under the Sun.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p:
The Third is an old Beau, that has May in his Fancy and Dreſs, but December in his Face and his Heels;
he admires nothing but new Faſhions, and thoſe muſt be French; loves Operas, Balls, Maſquerades, and is always the moſt tawdry of the whole Company on a Birth-day.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Theſe are pretty oppoſite to one another, truly! And the fourth, what is he, Landlord?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: A very rigid Quaker, whoſe Quarter begun this Day—I ſaw Mrs. Lovely go in not above two Hours ago—Sir Philip ſet her down. What think you now, Colonel, is not the poor Lady to be pity'd?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, and reſcued too, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In my Opinion, that's impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There is nothing impoſſible to a Lover. What would not a Man attempt for a fine Woman and Thirty Thouſand Pounds? Beſides, my Honour is at Stake; I promis'd to deliver her—and ſhe bad me win her, and take her.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: That's fair, faith.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: If it depended upon Knight-Errantry, I ſhould not doubt your ſetting free the Damſel; but to have Avarice, Impertinence, Hypocrifie, and Pride, at once to deal with, requires more Cunning than generally attends a Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Fancy tells me I ſhall come off with Glory; I reſolve to try, however.—Do you know all the Guardians, Mr. Sackbut?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, they all uſe my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And will you aſſiſt me, if occaſion be?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: In every thing I can, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I'll anſwer for him; and whatever I can ſerve you in, you may depend on. I know Mr. Periwinkle and Mr. Tradelove; the latter has a very great Opinion of my Intereſt Abroad.—I happen'd to have a Letter from a Correſpondent two Hours before the News arrived of the French King's Death; I communicated it to him; upon which he bought up all the Stock he could, and what with that, and ſome Wagers he laid, he told me, he had got to the Tune of Five Hundred Pounds; ſo that I am much in his good Graces.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.p: I don't know but you may be of Service to me, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: If I can, command me, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Is it not poſſible to find a Suit of Cloaths ready made at ſome of theſe Sale Shops, fit to rig out a Beau, think you, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: O hang 'em—No, Colonel, they keep nothing ready-made that a Gentleman would be ſeen in: But I can fit you with a Suit of Cloaths, if you'd make a Figure—Velvet and Gold Brocade—they were pawn'd to me by a French Count, who had been ſtript at Play, and wanted Money to carry him home; he promis'd to ſend for them, but I have heard nothing from him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: He has not fed upon Frogs long enough yet to recover his Loſs; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha, ha,—Well, thoſe Cloaths will do, Mr. Sackbut—tho' we muſt have three or four Fellows in tawdry Liveries; thoſe can be procur'd, I hope.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Egad, I have a Brother come from the Weſt-Indies, that can match you; and, for Expedition ſake, you ſhall have his Servants; there's a Black, a Tawny-moor, and a Frenchman; they don't ſpeak one Word of Engliſh, ſo can make no Miſtake.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Excellent—Egad, I ſhall look like an Indian Prince. Firſt I'll attack my Beau-Guardian; where lives he?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Faith, ſomewhere about St. James's; tho' to ſay in what Street, I cannot; but any Chairman will tell you where Sir Philip Modelove lives.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Oh! you'll find him in the Park at Eleven every Day; at leaſt I never paſs'd thro' at that Hour without ſeeing him there.—But what do you intend?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To addreſs him in his own Way, and find what he deſigns to do with the Lady.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And what then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, that I can't tell, but I ſhall take my Meaſures accordingly.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Well, 'tis a mad Undertaking, in my Mind; but here's to your Succeſs, Colonel. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Tis ſomething out of the Way, I confeſs; but Fortune may chance to ſmile, and I ſucceed—Come, Landlord, let me ſee thoſe Cloaths. Freeman, I ſhall expect you'll leave Word with Mr. Sackbut, where one may find you upon occaſion; and ſend my Equipage of India immediately, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Immediately.

l.hi: Bold was the Man who ventur'd firſt to Sea,
But the firſt vent'ring Lovers bolder were:
The Path of Love's a dark and dangerous Way,
Without a Landmark, or one friendly Star,
And he that runs the Riſque, deſerves the Fair.

div.head: SCENE II. Prim's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Lovely and her Maid Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Madam! why do you fret and teaze your ſelf ſo? This is giving them the Advantage with a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Muſt I be condemned all my Life to the prepoſterous Humours of other People; and pointed at by every Boy in Town?—Oh! I could tear my Fleſh, and curſe the Hour I was born.—Is it not monſtrouſly ridiculous, that they ſhould deſire to impoſe their Quaking Dreſs upon me at theſe Years? When I was a Child, no matter what they made me wear; but now—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I wou'd reſolve againſt it, Madam; I'd ſee 'em hang'd before I'd put on the pinch'd Cap again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Then I muſt never expect one Moment's Eaſe; ſhe has rung ſuch a Peal in my Ears already, that I ſhan't have the right Uſe of them this Month—What can I do?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What can you not do, if you will but give your Mind to it? Marry, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: What! and have my Fortune go to build Churches and Hoſpitals?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, let it go—If the Colonel loves you, as he pretends, he'll marry you without a Fortune, Madam; and I aſſure you, a Colonel's Lady is no deſpicable thing; a Colonel's Poſt will maintain you like a Gentlewoman, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: So you wou'd adviſe me to give up my own Fortune, and throw my ſelf upon the Colonel's.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I would adviſe you to make your ſelf eaſie, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: That's not the Way, I am ſure. No, no, Girl, there are certain Ingredients to be mingled with Matrimony, without which, I may as well change for the worſe as for the better. When the Woman has Fortune enough to make the Man happy, if he has either Honour or Good Manners, he'll make her eaſie. Love makes but a ſlovenly Figure in that Houſe, where Poverty keeps the Door.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And ſo you reſolve to die a Maid, do you Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Or have it in my Power to make the Man I love, Maſter of my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Then you don't like the Colonel ſo well as I thought you did, Madam, or you would not take ſuch a Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: It is becauſe I do like him, Betty, that I take ſuch a Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, do you expect, Madam, the Colonel can work Miracles? Is it poſſible for him to marry you with the Conſent of all your Guardians?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Or he muſt not marry me at all, and ſo I told him; and he did not ſeem diſpleas'd with the News.—He promis'd to ſet me free, and I, on the Condition, promis'd to make him Maſter of that Freedom.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
Well! I have read of inchanted Caſtles, Ladies delivered from the Chains of Magick, Giants kill'd, and Monſters overcome; ſo that I ſhall be the leſs ſurpriz'd, if the Colonel ſhould conjure your
out of the Power of your Guardians: If he does, I am ſure he deſerves your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: And ſhall have it, Girl, if it were ten times as much—For I'll ingenuouſly confeſs to thee, that I do like the Colonel above all Men I ever ſaw—There's ſomething ſo Jantée in a Soldier, a kind of a Je ne ſcay quoi Air, that makes 'em more agreeable than the reſt of Mankind—They command Regard, as who ſhould ſay, We are your Defenders, We preſerve your Beauties from the Inſults of rude unpoliſh'd Foes, and ought to be preferr'd before thoſe lazy indolent Mortals, who by dropping into their Fathers Eſtate ſet up their Coaches, and think to rattle themſelves into our Affections.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, I confeſs that the Army has engroſs'd all the prettieſt Fellows—A lac'd Coat and Feather have irreſiſtable Charms.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: But the Colonel has all the Beauties of the Mind, as well as Perſon.—O all ye Powers, that favour happy Lovers, grant he may be mine! Thou God of Love, if thou be'ſt ought but Name, aſſiſt my Fainwell.

l.hi: Point all thy Darts to aid my Love's Deſign,
And make his Plots as prevalent as thine.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt ACT.

div.head: SCENE 1. SCENE the Park.
div.stage: Enter Colonel finely dreſt, three Footmen after him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So, now if I can but meet this Beau—'Egad, methinks I cut a ſmart Figure, and have as much of the tawdry Air, as any Italian Count, or French Marquée of 'em all—Sure I ſhall know this Knight again,—ah! yonder he ſits, making Love to a Mask, i'faith, I'll walk up the Mall, and come down by him.

div.stage: SCENE draws, and diſcovers Sir Philip upon a Bench with a Woman mask'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Well, but, my Dear, are you really conſtant to your Keeper?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Yes, really, Sir—hey day! who comes yonder, he cuts a mighty Figure.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha! A Stranger, by his Equipage keeping ſo cloſe at his Heels—He has the Appearance of a Man of Quality—Poſitively, French by his dancing Air.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: He croſſes, as if he meant to ſit down here.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: He has a mind to make love to thee, Child.—

div.stage: Enter Colonel, and ſeats himſelf upon the Bench by Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: It will be to no Purpoſe if he does.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Are you reſolv'd to be cruel then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You muſt be very cruel, indeed, if you can deny any thing to ſo fine a Gentleman, Madam. [Takes out his Watch.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: I never mind the Outſide of a Man.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And I'm afraid thou art no Judge of the Inſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I am poſitively of your Mind, Sir. For Creatures of her Function ſeldom penetrate beyond the Pocket.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Creatures of your Compoſition have, indeed, generally more in their Pockets than in their Heads. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Pray what ſays your Watch? mine is down. [Pulling out his Watch.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I want 36 Minutes of Twelve, Sir— [Puts up his Watch, and takes out his Snuff-Box.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: May I preſume, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir, you honour me. [Preſenting the Box.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: He ſpeaks good Engliſh—tho' he muſt be a Foreigner;—this Snuff is extreamly good—and the Box prodigious fine; the Work is French I preſume, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I bought it in Paris, Sir,—I do think the Workmanſhip pretty neat.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Neat! 'tis exquiſitely fine, Sir; pray, Sir, if I may take the Liberty of inquiring—what Country is ſo happy to claim the Birth of the fineſt Gentleman in the Univerſe? France, I preſume.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then you don't think me an Engliſhman?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: No, upon my Soul don't I.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am ſorry for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Impoſſible you ſhould wiſh to be an Engliſhman—Pardon me, Sir, this Iſland could not produce a Perſon of ſuch Alertneſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As this Mirrour ſhews you, Sir. [Puts up a Pocket-Glaſs to Sir Philip's Face.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Coxcombs! I'm ſick to hear 'em praiſe one another; one ſeldom gets any thing by ſuch Animals, not even a Dinner, unleſs one can dine upon Soop and Sallery.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: O Ged, Sir! Will you leave us, Madam? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
She fears 'twill be only loſing Time to ſtay here, ha, ha,—I know not how to diſtinguiſh you,
Sir, but your Mien and Addreſs ſpeak you Right Honourable.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Thus great Souls judge of others by themſelves—I am only adorn'd with Knighthood, that's all I aſſure you, Sir, my Name is Sir Philip Modelove.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Of French Extraction?—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: My Father was French.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: One may plainly perceive it—there is a certain Gaiety peculiar to my Nation, (for I will own my ſelf a Frenchman) which diſtinguiſhes us every where. A Perſon of your Figure would be a vaſt Addition to a Coronet.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I muſt own, I had the Offer of a Barony about five Years ago, but I abhorr'd the Fatigue which muſt have attended it—I could never yet bring my ſelf to join with either Party.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You are perfectly in the right, Sir Philip—a fine Perſon ſhould not embark himſelf in the ſlovenly Concern of Politicks; Dreſs and Pleaſure are Objects proper for the Soul of a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: And Love—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh! that's included under the Article of Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Parbleu, il eſt un homme d'eſprit, I muſt embrace you— [Riſes and embraces.] Your Sentiments are ſo agreeable to mine, that we appear to have but one Soul, for our Ideas and Conceptions are the ſame.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſorry for that [aſide.] You do me too much Honour, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Your Vivacity and Jantée Mien aſſured me at firſt ſight there was nothing of this foggy Iſland in your Compoſition. May I crave your Name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Name is La Fainwell, Sir, at you Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The La Fainwells are French, I know; tho' the Name is become very numerous in Great Britain of late Years.—I was ſure you was French the Moment I laid my Eyes upon you; I could not come in to the Suppoſition of your being an Engliſhman, this Iſland produces few ſuch Ornaments.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir Philip, this Iſland has two things ſuperior to all Nations under the Sun.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ay! what are they?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Ladies, and the Laws.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The Laws indeed do claim a Preference of other Nations,—but by my Soul there are fine Women every where—I muſt own I have felt their Power in all Countries.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There are ſome finiſh'd Beauties, I confeſs, in France, Italy, Germany, nay, even in Holland; mais ſont bien rare: But les belles Angloiſes!—Oh, Sir Philip, where find we ſuch Women! ſuch Symetry of Shape! ſuch Elegancy of Dreſs! ſuch Regularity of Features! ſuch Sweetneſs of Temper! ſuch commanding Eyes! and ſuch bewitching Smiles?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ah! parbleu vous eſtéz attrapér.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Non, je vous aſſure, Chevalier—but I declare there is no Amuſement ſo agreeable to my Goût, as the Converſation of a fine Woman—I could never be prevail'd upon to enter into what the Vulgar calls the Pleaſure of the Bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: My own Taſte, poſitivement—A Ball, or a Maſquerade, is certainly preferable to all the Productions of the Vineyard.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Infinitely! I hope the People of Quality in England will ſupport that Branch of Pleaſure, which was imported with their Peace, and ſince naturaliz'd by the ingenious Mr. Heidegger.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The Ladies aſſure me it will become Part of the Conſtitution,—upon which I ſubſcrib'd a hundred Guineas—it will be of great Service to the Publick, at leaſt to the Company of Surgeons, and the City in general.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha, ha, it may help to ennoble the Blood of the City. Are you married, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: No, nor do I believe I ever ſhall enter into that honourable State; I have an abſolute Tender for the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That's more than they have for you, I dare ſwear. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: And I have the Honour to be very well with the Ladies, I can aſſure you, Sir; and I won't affront a Million of fine Women, to make one happy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, Marriage is really reducing a Man's Taſte to a kind of half Pleaſure, but then it carries the Bleſſing of Peace along with it, one goes to ſleep without Fear, and wakes without Pain.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: There's ſomething of that in't; a Wife is a very good Diſh for an Engliſh Stomach—but groſs Feeding for nicer Palates, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I find I was very much miſtaken,—I imagin'd, you had been married to that young Lady which I ſaw in the Chariot with you this Morning in Grace-church-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Who, Nancy Lovely? I am a Piece of a Guardian to that Lady, you muſt know; her Father, I thank him, join'd me with three of the moſt prepoſterous old Fellows—that upon my Soul I'm in pain for the poor Girl,—ſhe muſt certainly lead Apes, as the Saying is; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That's pity, Sir Philip; if the Lady would give me leave, I would endeavour to avert that Curſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: As to the Lady, ſhe'd gladly be rid of us at any Rate, I believe; but here's the Miſchief, he who marries Miſs Lovely, muſt have the Conſent of us all four,—or not a Penny of her Portion.—For my Part, I ſhall never approve of any, but a Man of Figure,—and the reſt are not only averſe to Cleanlineſs, but have each a peculiar Taſte to gratify.—For my Part, I declare, I would prefer you to all Men I ever ſaw.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And I her to all Women—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Mr. Fainwell, I am for marrying her, for I hate the Trouble of a Guardian, eſpecially among ſuch Wretches; but reſolve never to agree to the Choice of any one of them,—and I fancy they'll be even with me, for they never came into any Propoſal of mine yet.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wiſh I had your Leave to try them, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: With all my Soul, Sir. I can refuſe a Perſon of your Appearance nothing.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir, I am infinitely oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: But do you really like Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I believe I could with that Lady, Sir,

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The only Point in which we differ—but you are Maſter of ſo many Qualifications, that I can excuſe one Fault, for I muſt think it a Fault in a fine Gentleman; and that you are ſuch, I'll give it under my hand.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wiſh you'd give me your Conſent to marry Mrs. Lovely under your Hand, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I'll do'r, if you'll ſtep into St. James's Coffee-Houſe, where we may have Pen and Ink—tho' I can't foreſee what Advantage my Conſent will be to you, without you could find a way to get the reſt of the Guardians—but I'll introduce you however, ſhe is now at a Quaker's where I carried her this Morning, when you ſaw us in Grace-church-ſtreet.—I aſſure you ſhe has an odd Ragoût of Guardians, as you will find when you hear the Characters, which I'll endeavour to give you as we go along—Hey! Pierre, Jaque, Renno—where are you all, Scoundrels?—Order the Chariot to St. James's Coffee-Houſe.

p.hi: Le Noir, la Brun, le Blanc—Mortblu, ou ſont ces Coquins-la? Alons, Monſieur le Chevalier.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ah! Pardonnez moy, Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Not one Step upon my Soul, Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: The beſt-bred Man in Europe, poſitively.

head.hi: SCENE Changes to Obediah Prim's Houſe.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Lovely, follow'd by Mrs. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Then thou wilt not obey me; and thou do'ſt really think thoſe Fallals becometh thee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I do, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Now will I be judged by all ſober People, if I don't look more like a modeſt Woman than thou doſt, Anne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: More like a Hypocrite you mean, Mrs. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Ah! Anne, Anne, that wicked Philip Modelove will undo thee—Satan ſo fills thy Heart with Pride, during the three Months of his Guardianſhip, that thou becomeſt a Stumbling-block to the Upright.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Pray who are they? Are the pinch'd Cap, and formal Hood, the Emblems of Sanctity? Does your Virtue conſiſt in your Dreſs, Mrs. Prim?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: It doth not conſiſt in cut Hair, ſpotted Face, and bare Necks,—Oh the Wickedneſs of this Generation! The Primitive Women knew not the Abomination of hoop'd Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: No, nor the Abomination of Cant neither. Don't tell me, Mrs. Prim, don't—I know you have as much Pride, Vanity, Self-conceit and Ambition among you, couch'd under that formal Habit, and ſanctify'd Countenance, as the proudeſt of us all; but the World begins to ſee your Prudry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Prudry! What! do they invent new Words as well as new Faſhions? Ah! poor fantaſtick Age, I pity thee—poor deluded Anne; Which doſt thou think moſt reſembleſt the Saint, and which the Sinner, thy Dreſs, or mine? Thy naked Boſom allureth the Eye of the By-ſtander—encourageth the Frailty of Humane Nature—and corrupteth the Soul with evil Longings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: And pray who corrupted your Son Tobias with evil Longings? Your Maid Tabitha wore a Handkerchief, and yet he made the Saint a Sinner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Well, well, ſpit thy Malice—I confeſs Satan did buffet my Son Tobias, and my Servant Tabitha; the Evil Spirit was at that time too ſtrong, and they both became ſubject to its Workings—not from any outward Provocation—but from an inward Call;—he was not tainted with the Rottenneſs of the Faſhions, nor did his Eyes take in the Drunkenneſs of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: No! that's plainly to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Tabitha is one of the Faithful, he fell not with a Stranger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: So! Then you hold Wenching no Crime, provided it be within the Pale of your own Tribe—you are an excellent Caſuiſt truly.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Not ſtripp'd of thy Vanity yet, Anne! Why doſt not thou make her put it off, Sarah?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: She will not do it.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Verily, thy naked Breaſts troubleth my outward Man; I pray thee hide 'em, Anne; put on a Handkerchief, Anne Lovely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I hate Handkerchiefs when 'tis not cold Weather, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: I have ſeen thee wear a Handkerchief; nay, and a Mask to boot, in the middle of July.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Ay, to keep the Sun from ſcorching me.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: If thou cou'd'ſt not bear the Sun-beams, how doſt thou think Man ſhou'd bear thy Beams? Thoſe Breaſts inflame Deſire, let them be hid, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Let me be quiet, I ſay:—Muſt I be tormented thus for ever? Sure no Woman's Condition ever equal'd mine; Foppery, Folly, Avarice and Hypocriſy, are by Turns my conſtant Companions,—and I muſt vary Shapes as often as a Player.—I cannot think my Father meant this Tyranny! No; you uſurp an Authority which he never intended you ſhou'd take.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Hark thee, Do'ſt thou call good Counſel Tyranny? Do I, or my Wife, tyrannize, when we deſire thee in all Love to put off thy Tempting Attire, and vail thy Provokers to Sin?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Deliver me, good Heaven! or I ſhall go diſtracted. [Walks about.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p:
So! now thy Pinners are toſt, and thy Breaſts pull'd up;—verily they were ſeen enough
before;—fie upon the filthy Taylor who made them Stays.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I wiſh I were in my Grave! Kill me rather than treat me thus.—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Kill thee! ha, ha; thou think'ſt thou art Acting ſome lude Play ſure;—kill thee! Art thou prepar'd for Death, Anne Lovely? No, no, thou wou'dſt rather have a Husband, Anne:—Thou wanteſt a Gilt Coach, with ſix lazy Fellows behind, to flant it in the Ring of Vanity—among the Princes and Rulers of the Land,—who pamper themſelves with the Fatneſs thereof; but I will take care that none ſhall ſquander away thy Father's Eſtate; thou ſhalt marry none ſuch, Anne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Wou'd you marry me to one of your own Canting Sex?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Yea, verily, no ne elſe ſhall ever get myonſent, I do aſſure thee, Anne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: And I do aſſure thee, Obadiah, that I will as ſoon turn Papiſt, and dye in a Convent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Oh Wickedneſs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Oh Stupidity!

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Oh Blindneſs of Heart!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Thou Blinder of the World, don't provoke me—leſt I betray your Sanctity, and leave your Wife to judge of your Purity:—What were the Emotions of your Spirit,—when you ſqueez'd Mary by the Hand laſt Night in the Pantry,—when ſhe told you, you buſs'd ſo filthily? Ah! you had no Averſion to naked Boſoms, when you begg'd her to ſhow you a little, little, little Bit of her delicious Bubby:—don't you remember thoſe Words, Mr. Prim?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: What does ſhe ſay, Obadiah?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: She talketh unintelligibly, Sarah. Which Way did ſhe hear this? This ſhou'd not have reach'd the Ears of the wicked ones;—verily, it troubleth me, [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Philip Modelove, whom they call Sir Philip, is below, and ſuch another with him, ſhall I ſend them up?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: How do'ſt thou do, Friend Prim; odſo! my She-Friend here too! What, you are documenting Miſs Nancy, reading her a Lecture upon the pinch'd Coif, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: I am ſure thou never readeſt her any Lecture that was good.—My Fleſh riſeth ſo at theſe wicked Ones, that Prudence adviſeth me to withdraw from their Sight.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Oh! that I cou'd find Means to ſpeak to her! How charming ſhe appears! I wiſh I cou'd get this Letter into her Hand. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Well, Miſs Cockey, I hope thou haſt got the better of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: The Difficulties of my Life are not to be ſurmounted, Sir Philip,—I hate the Impertinence of him, as much as the Stupidity of the other. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Prim.
sp.p: Verily, Philip, thou wilt ſpoil this Maiden.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I find we ſtill differ in Opinion; but that we may none of us ſpoil her, pr' ythee, Prim, let us conſent to marry her—I have ſent for our Brother Guardians to meet me here about that very Thing.—Madam, will you give me Leave to recommend a Husband to you.—Here's a Gentleman, which, in my Mind, you can have no Objection to.

div.stage: [Preſents the Colonel to her, ſhe looks another Way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Heaven deliver me from the Formal, and the Fantaſtick Fool. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
A fine Woman,—a fine Horſe, and fine Equipage, are the fineſt Things in the Univerſe:—And if I am ſo happy to poſſeſs you, Madam, I ſhall become
the Envy of Mankind, as much as you out-ſhine your whole Sex. [As he takes her Hand to kiſs it, he endeavours to put the Letter into it, ſhe lets it drop,—Prim takes it up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I have no Ambition to appear conſpicuouſly ridiculous, Sir. [Turning from him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So fall the Hopes of Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Ha! Fainwell! 'tis he! What have I done? Prim has the Letter, and all will be diſcover'd. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Friend, I know not thy Name, ſo cannot call thee by it; but thou ſeeſt thy Letter is unwelcome to the Maiden, ſhe will not read it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha! Right Woman, faith!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Excellent Woman. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Friend, thy Garb ſavoureth too much of the Vanity of the Age for my Approbation; nothing that reſembleth Philip Modelove ſhall I love, mark that;—therefore, Friend Philip, bring no more of thy own Apes under my Roof.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I am ſo entirely a Stranger to the Monſters of thy Breed, that I ſhall bring none of them, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am likely to have a pretty Task by that time I have gone thro' them all; but ſhe's a City worth taking, and 'egad I'll carry on the Siege: If I can but blow up the Out-works, I fancy I am pretty ſecure of the Town. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Toby Periwinkle and Thomas Tradelove demandeth to ſee thee. [To Sir Philip.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Bid them come up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p:
Deliver me from ſuch an Inundation of Noiſe and Nonſenſe. Oh Fainwell! whatever thy Contrivance
is, proſper it Heaven;—but oh! I fear thou never canſt redeem me.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Theſe are my Brother Guardians, Mr. Fainwell; pr'ythee obſerve the Creatures. [Aſide to the Col.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.p: Well, Sir Philip, I obey your Summons.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray, what have you to offer for the Good of Mrs. Lovely, Sir Philip?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Firſt I deſire to know what you intend to do with that Lady? Muſt ſhe be ſent to the Indies for a Venture,—or live to be an old Maid, and then enter'd amongſt your Curioſities, and ſhewn for a Monſter, Mr. Periwinkle?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Humph, Curioſities! that muſt be the Virtuoſo. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why, what wou'd you do with her?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: I wou'd recommend this Gentleman to her for a Husband, Sir—a Perſon whom I have pick'd out from the whole Race of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: I wou'd adviſe thee to ſhuffle him again with the reſt of Mankind, for I like him not.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, without Offence to your Formality, what may be your Objections?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Thy Perſon; thy Manners; thy Dreſs; thy Acquaintance;—thy every Thing, Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: You are moſt particularly obliging, Friend, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.p: What Buſineſs do you follow, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Humph, by that Queſtion he muſt be the Broker. [Aſide.] —Buſineſs, Sir! the Buſineſs of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.p: That is as much as to ſay, you dreſs fine, feed high, lie with every Woman you like, and pay your Surgeon's Bills better than your Taylors or your Butchers.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Court is much oblig'd to you, Sir, for your Character of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.p: The Court, Sir! What wou'd the Court do without us Citizens?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Without your Wives and Daughters you mean, Mr. Tradelove?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Have you ever travell'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That Queſtion muſt not be anſwer'd now—In Books I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: In Books? That's fine travelling indeed!—Sir Philip, when you preſent a Perſon I like, he ſhall have my Conſent to marry Mrs. Lovely, 'till when, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'll make you like me before I have done with you, or I am miſtaken. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Trad.
sp.p: And when you can convince me, that a Beau is more uſeful to my Country than a Merchant, you ſhall have mine: 'till then you muſt excuſe me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So much for Trade,—q'll fit you too. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: In my Opinion, this is very inhumane Treatment, as to the Lady, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Thy Opinion and mine happens to differ as much as our Occupations, Friend; Buſineſs requireth my Preſence, and Folly thine, and ſo I muſt bid thee farewel.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Here's Breeding for you, Mr. Fainwel!—Gad take me, I'd give half my Eſtate to ſee theſe Raſcals bit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope to bite you all, if my Plots hit. [Aſide.

div.head: SCENE I. SCENE the Tavern;
div.stage: Sackbut, and the Colonel in an Aegyptian Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: A Lucky Beginning, Colonel—you have got the old Beau's Conſent.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, he's a reaſonable Creature; but the other three will require ſome Pains—Shall I paſs upon him, think you? Egad, in my Mind, I look as Antique as if I had been preſerv'd in the Ark.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Paſs upon him! ay, ay, as roundly as White-wine daſh'd with Sack does for Mountain and Sherry, if you have but Aſſurance enough—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have no Apprehenſion from that Quarter; Aſſurance is the Cockade of a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Ay, but the Aſſurance of a Soldier differs much from that of a Traveller—Can you lye with a good Grace?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As heartily when my Miſtreſs is the Prize, as I would meet the Foe when my Country call'd, and King commanded; ſo don't you fear that Part; if he don't know me again I'm ſaſe—I hope he'll come.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: I wiſh all my Debts would come as ſure. I told him you had been a great Traveller, had many valuable Curioſities, and was a Perſon of a moſt ſingular Taſte; he ſeem'd tranſported, and begg'd me to keep you till he came.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.p: Ay, ay, he need not fear my running away—Let's have a Bottle of Sack, Landlord, our Anceſtors drank Sack.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: You ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And where-abouts is the Trap-door you mentioned?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: There's the Conveyance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Now if I ſhould cheat all theſe Roguiſh Guardians, and carry off my Miſtreſs in Triumph, it would be what the French call a Grand Coup d'Eclat—Odſo! here comes Periwinkle—Ah! duce take this Beard, pray Jupiter it does not give me the ſlip, and ſpoil all.

div.stage: Enter Sackbut with Wine, and Periwinkle following.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Sir, this Gentleman hearing you have been a great Traveller, and a Perſon of fine Speculation, begs leave to take a Glaſs with you; he is a Man of a curious Taſte himſelf.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Gentleman has it in his Face and Garb: Sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Sir, I honour a Traveller, and Men of your enquiring Diſpoſition; the Oddneſs of your Habit pleaſes me extreamly; 'tis very Antique, and for that I like it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Tis very Antique, Sir;—This Habit once belong'd to the famous Claudius Ptolomeus, who liv'd in the Year a Hundred and Thirty Five.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: If he keeps up to the Sample, he ſhall lye with the Devil for a Bean-Stack, and win it every Straw. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: A Hundred and Thirty Five! why, that's prodigious now—Well, certainly 'tis the fineſt thing in the World to be a Traveller.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: For my part I value none of the modern Faſhions of a Fig-Leaf.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: No more do I, Sir; I had rather be the Jeſt of a Fool, than his Favourite,—I am laugh'd at her for my Singularity—This Coat you muſt know, Sir, was formerly worn by that Ingenious and very Learned Perſon, John Tradeſcant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
John Tradeſcant! Let me embrace you, Sir—John Tradeſcant was my Uncle, by Mother-ſide; and
I thank you for the Honour you do his Memory; he was a very curious Man indeed.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Uncle, Sir,—Nay then, 'tis no wonder that your Taſte is ſo refin'd; why, you have it in your Blood—My humble Service to you, Sir, to the immortal Memory of John Tradeſcant, your never-to-be-forgotten Uncle. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Give me a Glaſs, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I find you are Primitive, even in your Wine; Canary was the Drink of our wiſe Forefathers; 'tis Balſamick, and ſaves the Charge of Apothecaries Cordials.—Oh! that I had liv'd in your Uncle's Days! or rather, that he were now alive;—Oh! how proud he'd be of ſuch a Nephew!

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Oh Pox! that would have ſpoil'd the Jeſt. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: A Perſon of your Curioſity muſt have collected many Rarities.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have ſome, Sir, which are not yet come aſhore, as an Egyptian Idol.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray what might that be?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It is, Sir, a Kind of an Ape, which they formerly worſhipp'd in that Country; I took it from the Breaſt of a Female Mummy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ha, ha! our Women retain part of their Idolatry to this Day, for many an Ape lies on a Lady's Breaſt, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: A ſmart old Thief. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Two Tusks of an Hippotamus, two Pair of Chineſe Nut-crackers, and one Egyptian Mummy.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray, Sir have you never a Crocodile?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Humph! the Boatſwain brought one with Deſign to ſhew it, but touching at Rotterdam, and hearing it was no Rarity in England, he ſold it to a Dutch Poet.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: The Devil's in that Nation, it rivals us in every thing.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I ſhould have been very glad to have ſeen a living Crocodile.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My Genius led me to things more worthy my Regard—Sir, I have ſeen the utmoſt Limits of this Globular World; I have ſeen the Sun riſe and ſet; know in what Degree of Heat he is at Noon, to the Breadth of a Hair, and what Quantity of Combuſtibles he burns in a Day, how much of it turns to Aſhes, and how much to Cinders.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To Cinders? You amaze me Sir; I never heard that the Sun conſum'd any thing—Deſcartes tells us—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Deſcartes, with the reſt of his Brethren both ancient and modern, knew nothing of the Matter—I tell you Sir, that Nature admits an annual Decay, tho' imperceptible to vulgar Eyes—Sometimes his Rays deſtroy below, ſometimes above—You have heard of Blazing Comets, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I remember to have ſeen one; and our Aſtrologers tell us of another which ſhall happen very quickly.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Thoſe Comets are little Iſlands bordering on the Sun, which at certain Times are ſet on Fire by that Luminous Body's moving over them perpendicular, which will one Day occaſion a general Conflagration.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: One need not ſcruple the Colonel's Capacity, Faith [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is marvellous ſtrange! Theſe Cinders are what I never read of in any of our Learned Diſſertations.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I don't know how the Devil you ſhould. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: He has at this Fingers Ends; one would ſwear he had learned to lye at School, he does it ſo cleverly. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well! you Travellers ſee ſtrange things! Pray, Sir, have you any of thoſe Cinders?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have, among my other Curioſities.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Oh, what have I loſt for want of Travelling!—Pray what have you elſe?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Several Things worth your Attention—I have a Muff made of the Feathers of thoſe Geeſe that ſav'd the Roman Capitol.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Yes, if you are ſuch a Gooſe to believe him. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have an Indian Leaf which open, will cover an Acre of Land, yet folds up in ſo little a Compaſs, you may put it into your Snuff-Box.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Humph! that's a Thunderer. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ah! mine is but a little one; I have ſeen ſome of them that would cover one of the Carribian Iſlands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, if I don't travel before I die, I ſha'nt reſt in my Grave—Pray, what do the Indians with them?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Sir, they uſe them in their Wars for Tents, the Old Women for Ridinghoods, the Young for Fans and Umbrellas.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: He has a fruitful Invention. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I admire our Eaſt-India Company imports none of them, they would certainly find their Account in them.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Right, if they could find the Leaves. [Aſide.
—Look ye, Sir, do you ſee this little Vial?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray you, what is it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This is called Poluflosboio.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Poluflosboio!—it has a rumbling Sound.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Right, Sir. it proceeds from a rumbling Nature—This Water was part of thoſe Waves, which bore Cleopatra's Veſſel when ſhe ſail'd to meet Anthony.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, of all that ever travell'd, none had a Taſte like you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But here's the Wonder of the World—This, Sir, is called Zona, or Moros Muſphonon, the Virtues of this is ineſtimable.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Moros Muſphonon! What, in the Name of Wiſdom, can that be?—to me it ſeems a plain Belt.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This Girdle has carried me all the World over.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You have carried it, you mean.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I mean as I ſay, Sir—Whenever I am girded with this, I am inviſible; and by turning this little Screw, can be in the Court of the Great Mogul, the Grand Seignior, and King George, in as little Time as your Cook can poach an Egg.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You muſt pardon me, Sir, I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If my Landlord pleaſes, he ſhall try the Experiment immediately.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, Sir, but I have no Inclination to ride Poſt to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, no, you fhan't ſtir a Foot, I'll only make you inviſible.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: But if you could not make me viſible again.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Come try it upon me, Sir, I am not afraid of the Devil, nor all his Tricks.—Zbud, I'll ſtand 'em all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There, Sir, put it on—Come, Landlord, you and I muſt face the Eaſt. [They turn about.] Is it on, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis on. [They turn about again.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Heaven protect me! where is he?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why here, juſt where I was.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Where, where, in the Name of Virtue? Ah, poor Mr. Periwinkle!—Egad look to't, you had beſt, Sir, and let him be ſeen again, or I ſhall have you burnt for a Wizzard.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Have Patience, good Landlord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But really don't you ſee me now?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: No more than I ſee my Grandmother that dy'd forty Years ago.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Are you ſure you don't lye? Methinks I ſtand juſt where I did, and ſee you as plain as I did before.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Ah! I wiſh I could ſee you once again.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Take off the Girdle, Sir. [He takes it off.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, I am glad to ſee you with all my Heart. [Embraces him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is very odd; certainly there muſt be ſome Trick in't—Pray, Sir, will you do me the Favour to put it on your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: But firſt I'll ſecure the Door.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You know how to turn the Screw, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Yes, yes—Come Mr. Periwinkle, we muſt turn full Eaſt. [They turn, the Colonel ſinks down a Trap-door.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Tis done, now turn. [They turn.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ha! Mercy upon me! My Fleſh creeps upon my Bones—This muſt be a Conjurer, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: He is the Devil, I think.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Sackbut, why do you name the Devil, when perhaps he may be at your Elbow.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: At my Elbow! marry, Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Are you ſatisfied, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, yes—How hollow his Voice ſounds!

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Yours ſeem'd juſt the ſame—Faith, I wiſh this Girdle were mine, I'd ſell Wine no more. Hark ye, Mr. Periwinkle, [Takes him aſide till the Colonel riſes again.] if he would ſell this Girdle, you might travel with great Expedition.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But it is not to be parted with for Money.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am ſorry for't, Sir, becauſe I think it the greateſt Curioſity I ever heard of.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: By the Advice of a learned Phiſiognomiſt in Grand Cairo, who conſulted the Lines in my Face, I returned to England, where, he told me, I ſhould find a Rarity in the Keeping of four Men, which I was born to poſſeſs for the Benefit of Mankind, and the firſt of the four that gave me his Conſent, I ſhould preſent him with this Girdle—Till I have found this Jewel, I ſhall not part with the Girdle.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What can that Rarity be? Did he not name it to you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; he call'd it a Chaſte, Beautiful, Unaffected Woman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Piſh! Women are no Rarities.—I never had any great Taſte that Way. I married, indeed, to pleaſe a Father, and I got a Girl to pleaſe my Wife; but ſhe and the Child (thank Heaven) died together—Women are the very Gewgaws of the Creation; Play-things for Boys, which, when they write Man, they ought to throw aſide.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: A fine Lecture to be read to a Circle of Ladies! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What Woman is there, dreſt in all the Pride and Foppery of the Times, can boaſt of ſuch a Foretop as the Cockatoor.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I muſt humour him. [Aſide.] Such a Skin as the Lizzard?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Such a ſhining Breaſt as the Humming-Bird?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Such a Shape as the Antilope?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Or, in all the artful Mixture of their various Dreſſes, have they half the Beauty of one Box of Butterflies?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, that muſt be allow'd—For my part, if it were not for the Benefit of Mankind, I'd have nothing to do with them, for they are as indifferent to me, as a Sparrow or a Fleſh-Fly.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what Benefit is the World to reap from this Lady?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, Sir, ſhe is to bear me a Son, who ſhall reſtore the Art of Embalming, and the old Roman Manner of Burying their Dead; and, for the Benefit of Poſterity, he is to diſcover the Longitude, ſo long ſought for in vain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Od! theſe are very valuable Things, Mr. Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: He hits it off admirably, and t'other ſwallows it like Sack and Sugar. [Aſide.] Certainly this Lady muſt be your Ward, Mr. Periwinkle, by her being under the Care of four Perſons.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: By the Deſcription it ſhould—Egad, if I could get that Girdle, I'd ride with the Sun, and make the Tour of the whole World in four and twenty Hours [Aſide.] And are you to give that Girdle to the firſt of the four Guardiar s that ſhall give his Conſent to marry that Lady, ſay you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am ſo order'd, when I can find him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I fancy I know the very Woman—her Name is Ann Lovely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Excellent!—he ſaid, indeed, that the firſt Letter of her Name was L.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Did he really?—Well, that's prodigiouſly amazing, that a Perſon in Grand Cairo ſhould know any thing of my Ward.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Your Ward?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: To be plain with you, Sir, I am one of thoſe four Guardians.

sp.speaker: Col,
sp.p: Are you indeed, Sir? I am tranſported to find the Man who is to poſſeſs this Moros Muſphonon is a Perſon of ſo curious a Taſte—Here is a Writing drawn up by that famous Egyptian, which, if you will pleaſe to ſign, you muſt turn your Face full North, and the Girdle is yours.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If I live till this Boy is born, I'll be embalm'd and ſent to the Royal Society when I die.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That you ſhall moſt certainly.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here's Mr. Staytape the Taylor, enquires for you, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Who do you ſpeak to, you Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ha! Colonel! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Confound the blundering Dog! [Aſide

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Why, to Colonel—

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Get you out you Raſcal. [Kicks him out, and Exit after him.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What the Devil is the Matter?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This Dog has ruin'd all my Scheme, I ſee by Periwinkle's Looks. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How finely I ſhould have been chous'd—Colonel, you'll pardon me that I did not give your Title before—it was pure Ignorance, Faith it was—Pray—hem, hem—Pray, Colonel, what Poſt had this Learned Egyptian in your Regiment?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A Pox of your Snear [Aſide.] I don't underſtand you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: No? that's ſtrange! I underſtand you, Colonel—An Egyptian of Grand Cario! ha, ha, ha—I am ſorry ſuch a well-invented Tale ſhould do you no more Service—We old Fellows can ſee as far into a Mill-ſtone, as him that picks it—I am not to be trick'd out of my Truſt—mark that.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Devil! I muſt carry it off; I wiſh I were fairly out. [Aſide.] Look ye, Sir, you may make what Jeſt you pleaſe—but the Stars will be obey'd, Sir, and, depend upon it, I ſhall have the Lady, and you none of the Girdle—Now for Freeman's Part of the Plot. [Aſide.]

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The Stars! ha, ha—No Star has favour'd you, it ſeems—The Girdle! ha, ha, ha, none of your Lagerdemain's Tricks can paſs upon me—Why, what a Pack of Trumpery has this Rogue pick'd up?—His Pagod, Poluflosboios, his Zonas, Moros Muſphonons, and the Devil knows what—But I'll take Care—Ha gone?—Ay, 'twas time to ſneak off—Soho! the Houſe! [Enter Sackbut.] Where is this Trickſter? Send for a Conſtable, I'll have this Raſcal before the Lord Mayor; I'll Grand Cairo him, with a Pox to him—I believe you had a Hand in putting this Impoſture upon me, Sackbut.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Who I, Mr. Periwinkle? I ſcorn it; I perceiv'd he was a Cheat, and left the Room on purpoſe to ſend for a Conſtable to apprehend him, and endeavour'd to ſtop him when he went out—but the Rogue made but one Step from the Stairs to the Door, call'd a Coach, leapt into it, and drove away like the Devil, as Mr. Freeman can witneſs, who is at the Bar, and deſires to ſpeak with you; he is this Minute come to Town.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Send him in. [Exit Sackbut.] What a Scheme this Rogue had laid! How I ſhould have been laugh'd at, had it ſucceeded! [Enter Freeman Booted and Spurr'd.] Mr. Freeman, your Dreſs commands your Welcome to Town; what will you drink? I had like to have been impos'd upon here by the verieſt Raſcal—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am ſorry to hear it,—The Dog flew for't—he had not 'ſcap'd me, if I had been aware of him; Sackbut ſtruck at him, but miſs'd his Blow, or he had done his Buſineſs for him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I believe you never heard of ſuch a Contrivance, Mr. Freeman, as this Fellow had found out.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Mr. Sackbut has told me the whole Story, Mr. Periwinkle; but now I have ſomething to tell you of much more Importance to your ſelf—I happen'd to lie one Night at Coventry, and knowing your Uncle Sir Toby Periwinkle, I paid him a Viſit, and to my great Surprize found him dying.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Dying!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Dying, in all Appearance; the Servants weeping, the Room in Darkneſs; the Apothecary ſhaking his Head, told me, the Doctors had given him over; and then there is ſmall Hopes, you know.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I hope he has made his Will—he always told me, he wou'd make me his Heir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I have heard you ſay as much, and therefore reſolv'd to give you Notice. I ſhould think, it would not be amiſs if you went down to-morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: It is a long Journey, and the Roads very bad.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But he has a great Eſtate, and the Land very good—Think upon that.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why that's true, as you ſay; I'll think upon it: In the mean time I give you many Thanks for your Civility, Mr. Freeman, and ſhould be glad of your Company to dine with me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
I am oblig'd to be at Jonathan's Coffee-Houſe at Two, and it is now half an Hour after One; if I
diſpatch my Buſineſs, I'll wait on you; I know your Hour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You ſhall be very welcome, Mr. Freeman; and ſo your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,—I have done your Buſineſs, Colonel; he has ſwallow'd the Bait.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I overheard all, tho' I am a little in the dark: I am to perſonate a Highway-Man, I ſuppoſe—That's a Project I am not fond of; for tho' I may fright him out of his Conſent, he may fright me out of my Life when he diſcovers me, as he certainly muſt in the End.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, no, I have a Plot for you without Danger; but firſt we muſt manage Tradelove—Has the Taylor brought your Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Yes, Pox take the Thief.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pox take your Drawer, for a jolt-headed Rogue.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, well, no matter, I warrant we have him yet—But now you muſt put on the Dutch Merchant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Duce of this Trading-Plot—I wiſh he had been an old Soldier, that I might have attack'd him in my own Way, heard him fight over all the Battles of the Civil War—but for Trade, by Jupiter I ſhall never do it.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Never fear, Colonel, Mr. Freeman will inſtruct you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You'll ſee what others do, the Coffee-houſe will inſtruct you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I muſt venture, however—But I have a farther Plot in my Head upon Tradelove, which you muſt aſſiſt me in Freeman; you are in Credit with him, I heard you ſay.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am, and will ſcruple nothing to ſerve you, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come along then—Now for the Dutchman—Honeſt Ptolomy, by your Leave,

l.hi: Now muſt Bob-Wig and Buſineſs come in Play,
And a fair Thirty Thouſand Pounder leads the Way.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I. SCENE, Jonathan's Coffee-Houſe in Exchange-Alley. Crowd of People with Rolls of Paper and Parchment in their Hands; a Bar, and Coffee-Boys waiting.
div.stage: Enter Tradelove, and Stockjobbers with Rolls of Paper and Parchment.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Stock.
sp.p: SOuth-Sea at ſeven Eights! who buys?

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.p: South Sea Bonds due at Michaelmas, 1718. Claſs-Lottery Tickets.

sp.speaker: 3d Stock.
sp.p: Eaſt India Bonds?

sp.speaker: 4th Stock.
sp.p: What all Sellers and no Buyers? Gentlemen, I'll buy a thouſand Pound for Tueſday next at 3 Fourths.

sp.speaker: Coff. B.
sp.p: Freſh Coffee, Gentlemen, freſh Coffee?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Hark ye, Gabriel, you'll pay the Difference of that Stock we tranſacted for t'other Day.

sp.speaker: Gabr.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Tradelove, here's a Note for the Money, upon the Sword-Blade Company. [Gives him a Note.

sp.speaker: Coff. B.
sp.p: Bohea-Tea, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Is Mr. Smuggle here?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Coff. B.
sp.p: Mr. Smuggle's not here, Sir, you'll find him at the Books.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.p: Ho! here come two Sparks from the other End of the Town; what News bring they?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I would fain Bite that Spark in the brown Coat, he comes very often into the Alley, but never employs a Broker.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.p: Who does any thing in the Civil Liſt Lottery? or Caco? Zounds, where are all the Jews this Afternoon? Are you a Bull or a Bear to day, Abraham?

sp.speaker: 3d Stock.
sp.p: A Bull, faith,—but I have a good Putt for next Week.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Mr. Freeman your Servant! Who is that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A Dutch Merchant, juſt come to England; but hark yee, Mr. Tradelove,—I have a Piece of News will get you as much as the French King's Death did, if you are expeditious.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir! Pray, what is it?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: [Showing him a Letter.] Read there, I receiv'd it juſt now from one that belongs to the Emperor's Miniſter.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: [Reads.] Sir, As I have many Obligations to you, I cannot miſs any Opportunity to ſhow my Gratitude; this Moment my Lord has receiv'd a private Expreſs, that the Spaniards have rais'd their Siege from before Cagliari; if this prove any Advantage to you, it will anſwer both the Ends and Wiſhes of, Sir, Your moſt obliged humble Servant, Henricus Duſſeldorp.
Poſtſcript. In two or three Hours the News will be publick.
May one depend upon this, Mr. Freeman? [Aſide to Freeman.]

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You may—I never knew this Perſon ſend me a falſe Piece of News in my Life.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Sir, I am much oblig'd to you, 'Egad 'tis rare News.—Who ſells South Sea for next Week?

sp.speaker: Stock.
sp.p: Job. [All together.] I ſell; I, I, I, I, I ſell.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Stock.
sp.p: I'll ſell 5000 l. for next Week, at five Eighths.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.p: —I'll ſell ten thouſand at five Eighths for the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, hold, hold, not all together, Gentlemen, I'll be no Bull, I'll buy no more than I can take:
Will you ſell ten thouſand Pound at a half, for any Day next Week, except Saturday?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Stock.
sp.p: I'll ſell it you, Mr. Tradelove.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: [Aloud.] The Spaniards rais'd the Siege of Cagliari! I don't believe one Word of it.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.p: Rais'd the Siege! as much as you have rais'd the Monument.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis rais'd I aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.p: What will you lay on't?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Gent.
sp.p: Why, I have a Brother upon the Spot, in the Emperor's Service; I am certain if there were any ſuch Thing, I ſhou'd have had a Letter.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.p: How's this? The Siege of Cagliari rais'd;—I wiſh it may be true, 'twill make Buſineſs ſtir, and Stocks riſe.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Stock.
sp.p: Tradelove's a cunning fat Bear; if this News proves true, I ſhall repent I ſold him the five thouſand Pounds.—Pray, Sir, what Aſſurance have you that the Siege is rais'd?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: There is come an Expreſs to the Emperor's Miniſter.

sp.speaker: 2d Stock.
sp.p: I'll know that preſently.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Gent.
sp.p: Let it come where it will, I'll hold you fifty Pounds 'tis falſe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: 2d Gent.
sp.p: I'll lay you a Brace of Hundreds upon the ſame.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I'll take you.

sp.speaker: 4th Stock.
sp.p: 'Egad, I'll hold twenty Pieces 'tis not rais'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Done, with you too.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I'll lay any Man a Brace of Thouſands the Siege is rais'd.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: The Dutch Merchant is your Man to take in. [Aſide to Tradelove.]

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Does not he know the News?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Not a Syllable; if he did, he wou'd bet a Hundred thouſand Pound as ſoon as one Penny;—
he's plaguy Rich, and a mighty Man at Wagers. [To Tradelove.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Say you ſo—'Egad, I'll bite him if poſſible:—Are you from Holland, Sir?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ya, Mynheer?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Had you the News before you came away?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wat believe you, Mynheer?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: What do I believe? Why, I believe that the Spaniards have actually rais'd the Siege of Cagliari.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wat Duyvels Niews is dat? 'Tis niet waer, Mynheer,—'tis no true, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo true, Mynheer, that I'll lay you two thouſand Pounds upon it—You are ſure the Letter may be depended upon, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Do you think I would venture my Money if I were not ſure of the Truth of it? [Aſide to Trade.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Two duyſend Pond, Mynheer, 'tis gedaen—dis Gentleman ſal hold de Gelt. [Gives Freeman Money.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: With all my Heart,—this binds the Wager.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: You have certainly loſt, Mynheer, the Siege is raiſed indeed.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ik gelove't niet, Mynheer Freeman, ik ſal ye dubbled houden, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am let into the Secret, therefore won't win your Money.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I have ſnapt the Dutchman, faith, ha, ha! this is no ill Day's Work,—pray may I crave your Name, Mynheer?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Myn Naem, Mynheer! myn Naem is, Jan van Timtamtirelereletta Heer van Fainwell?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Zounds 'tis a damn'd long Name, I ſhall never remember it—Myn Heer van Tim, Tim, Tim,—What the Devil is it?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Oh! never heed, I know the Gentleman, and will paſs my Word for twice the Sum.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: That's enough.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You'll hear of me ſooner than you'll wiſh old Gentleman, I fancy. [aſide.] You'll come to Sackbut's, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Immediately. [Aſide to the Colonel.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Man.
sp.p: Humphrey Hump here?

sp.speaker: 2d Boy.
sp.p: Mr. Humprey Hump is not here; you'll find him upon the Dutch Walk.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Mr. Freeman, I give you many Thanks for your Kindneſs.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I fear you'll repent when you know all. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Will you dine with me?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am engag'd at Sackbut's; adieu.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant. Now I'll ſee what I can do upon Change with my News.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! the old Fellow ſwallow'd the Bait as greedily as a Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have him, faith, ha, ha, ha—His two thouſand Pounds ſecure—if he wou'd keep his Money, he muſt part with the Lady, ha, ha—What came of your two Friends? they perform'd their Part very well; you ſhould have brought 'em to take a Glaſs with us.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No matter, we'll drink a Bottle together another Time,—I did not care to bring them hither; there's no Neceſſity to truſt them with the main Secret, you know, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Nay, that's right, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Joy, Joy, Colonel! the luckieſt Accident in the World!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What ſay'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: This Letter does your Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: (Reads.) To Obediah Prim, Hoſier, near the Building call'd the Monument, in London.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A Letter to Prim; how came you by it?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Looking over the Letters our Poſt-Woman brought, as I always do, to ſee what Letters are directed to my Houſe, (for ſhe can't read you muſt know) I ſpy'd this to Prim, ſo paid for't among the reſt; I have given the old Jade a Pint of Wine on purpoſe to delay Time, 'till you ſee if the Letter will be of any Service; then I'll ſeal it up again, and tell her I took it by Miſtake;—I have read it, and fancy you'll like the Project—read, read, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: [Reads.] Friend Prim, there is arriv'd from Penſilvania, one Simon Pure, a Leader of the Faithful, who hath ſojourn'd with us eleven Days, and hath been of great Comfort to the Brethren—He intendeth for the Quarterly Meeting in London; I have recommended him to thy Houſe; I pray thee intreat him kindly, and let thy Wife cheriſh him, for he's of weakly Conſtitution—he will depart from us the third Day; which is all from thy Friend in the Faith, Aminadad Holdfaſt.
Ha, ha! Excellent! I underſtand you, Landlord, I am to perſonate this Simon Pure, am I not?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Don't you like the Hint?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Admirably well!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis the beſt Contrivance in the World, if the right Simon gets not there before you.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, no, the Quakers never ride Poſt; he can't be here before to-morrow at ſooneſt: Do you ſend and buy me a Quaker's Dreſs, Mr. Sackbutt; and ſuppoſe, Freeman, you ſhould wait at the Briſtol Coach, that if you ſee any ſuch Perſon, you might contrive to give me Notice—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I will—the Country Dreſs and Boots, are they ready?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Yes, yes, every thing—Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Bring 'em in then,— [Exit Sack.] Thou muſt diſpatch Periwinkle firſt,—remember his Uncle Sir Toby Periwinkle is an old Batchelor of ſeventy five,—that he has ſeven hundred a Year, moſt in Abbey-Land; that he was once in Love with your Mother, and ſhrewdly ſuſpected by ſome to be your Father,—that you
have been thirty Years his Steward,—and ten Years his Gentleman—remember to improve theſe Hints.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Never fear, let me alone for that,—but what's the Steward's Name?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: His Name is Pillage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Enough— [Enter Sackbut with Clothes.] Now for the Country Put— [Dreſſes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Egad, Landlord, thou deſerveſt to have the firſt Night's Lodging with the Lady for thy Fidelity;—What ſay you, Colonel, ſhall we ſettle a Club here, you'll make one?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Make one; I'll bring a Sett of honeſt Officers, that will ſpend their Money as freely to the King's Health, as they would their Blood in his Service.

sp.speaker: Sack.
