sp.p: I thank you, Colonel. Here, here. [Bell rings.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So now for my Boots. [Puts on Boots.] Shall I find you here, Freeman, when I come back?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes,—or I'll leave Word with Sackbut, where he may ſend for me—Have you the Writings? the Will,—and every thing?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: All, all!—

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Zounds! Mr. Freeman! yonder is Tradelove in the damned'ſt Paſſion in the World.—He ſwears you are in the Houſe,—he ſays you told him you was to dine here.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I did ſo. Ha, ha, ha! he has found himſelf bit already.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Devil! he muſt not ſee me in this Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: I told him I expected you here, but you were not come yet.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Very well,—make you haſte out,! Colonel, and let me alone to deal with him: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: In the King's-Head.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You remember what I told you?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, ay, very well. Landlord, let him know I am come in,—and now, Mr. Pillage, ſucceſs attend you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Mr. Proteus rather.—
sp.l: From changing Shape and imitating Jove,

l.hi: I draw the happy Omens of my Love.
I'm not the firſt young Brother of the Blade
Who made his Fortune in a Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Zounds! Mr. Tradelove, we're bit it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Bit do you call it, Mr. Freeman? I am ruin'd,—Pox on your News.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Pox on the Raſcal that ſent it me.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Sent it you! Why Gabriel Skinſtint has been at the Miniſter's, and ſpoke with him, and he has aſſur'd him 'tis every Syllable falſe; he receiv'd no ſuch Expreſs.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I know it: I this Minute parted with my Friend, who proteſted he never ſent me any ſuch Letter,—ſome roguiſh Stockjobber has done it on purpoſe to make me loſe my Money, that's certain; I wiſh I knew who he was, I'd make him repent it—I have loſt three hundred Pounds by it.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: What ſignifies your 300 l. to what I have loſt? There's two thouſand Pounds to that Dutchman with the curſed long Name, beſides the Stock I bought; the Devil! I cou'd tear my Fleſh,—I muſt never ſhow my Face upon Change more,—for, by my Soul, I can't pay it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am heartily ſorry for't! What can I ſerve you in? Shall I ſpeak to the Dutch Merchant, and try to get you Time for the Payment?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Time! 'Ad'sheart! I ſhall never be able to look up again.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am very much concern'd that I was the Occaſion, and wiſh I could be an Inſtrument of retrieving your Misfortune; for my own I value it not.—'Adſo! a Thought comes into my Head, that well improv'd, may be of Service.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Ah! there's no Thought can be of any Service to me, without paying the Money, or running away.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How do you know? What do you think of my propoſing Mrs. Lovely to him? He is a ſingle Man,—and I heard him ſay he had a mind to marry an Engliſh Woman—nay, more than that, he ſaid ſomebody told him, you had a pretty Ward—he wiſh'd you had betted her inſtead of your Money.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Ay, but he'd be hang'd before he'd take her inſtead of the Money; the Dutch are too covetous for that; beſides, he did not know that there were three more of us I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So much the better; you may venture to give him your Conſent, if he'll forgive you the Wager: It is not your Buſineſs to tell him, that your Conſent will ſignifie nothing.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: That's right, as you ſay; but will he do it, think you?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I can't tell that; but I'll try what I can do with him—He has promis'd me to meet me here an Hour hence; I'll feel his Pulſe, and let you know: If I find it feaſible, I'll ſend for you; if not, you are at liberty to take what Meaſures you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: You muſt extol her Beauty, double her Portion, and tell him I have the entire Diſpoſal of her, and that ſhe can't marry without my Conſent;—and that I am a covetous Rogue, and will never part with her without a Valuable Conſideration.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let me alone for a Lye at a Pinch.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Egad, if you can bring this to bear, Mr. Freeman, I'll make you whole again; I'll pay the Three Hundred Pounds you loſt, with all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well, I'll uſe my beſt Endeavours—Where will you be?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: At Home; pray Heaven you proſper—If I were but the ſole Truſtee now, I ſhould not fear it. Who the Devil would be a Guardian,

l.hi: If when Caſh runs low, our Coffers t'enlarge,
We can't, like other Stocks, transfer our Charge?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—he has it.

div.stage: Enter Periwinkle on one Side, and Footman on t'other.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A Gentleman from Coventry enquires for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: From my Uncle, I warrant you, bring him up—This will ſave me the Trouble, as well as the Expences of a Journey.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Is your Name Periwinkle, Sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: It is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am ſorry for the Meſſage I bring—My old Maſter, whom I ſerved theſe forty Years, claims the Sorrow due from a faithful Servant to an indulgent Maſter. [Weeps.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: By this I underſtand, Sir, my Uncle Sir Toby Periwinkle is dead.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He is, Sir, and he has left you Heir to Seven Hundred a Year, in as good Abbey-Land as ever paid Peter-Pence to Rome—I wiſh you long to enjoy it, but my Tears will flow when I think of my Benefactor— [Weeps.] Ah! he was a good Man—he has not left many of his Fellows—the Poor laments him ſorely.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I pray, Sir, what Office bore you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I was his Steward, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I have heard him mention you with much Reſpect; your Name is—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pillage, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ay, Pillage! I do remember he call'd you Pillage—Pray, Mr. Pillage, when did my Uncle die?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Monday laſt, at Four in the Morning. About Two he ſigned this Will, and gave it into my Hands, and ſtrictly charged me to leave Coventry the Moment he expir'd, and deliver it to you with what Speed I could; I have obey'd him, Sir, and there is the Will. [Gives it to Per.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, I'll lodge it in the Commons.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: There are two Things which he forgot to inſert, but charged me to tell you, that he deſired you'd perform them as readily as if you had found them written in the Will, which is to remove his Corpſe, and bury him by his Father in St. Paul Covent-Garden, and to give all his Servants Mourning.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That will be a conſiderable Charge; a Pox of all modern Faſhions. [Aſide.] Well! it ſhall be done, Mr. Pillage; I will agree with one of Death's Faſhion-Mongers, call'd an Undertaker, to go down, and bring up the Body.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I ſhall have the Honour to ſerve you in the ſame Station I did your Worthy Uncle; I have not many Years to ſtay behind him, and would gladly ſpend them in the Family, where I was brought up— [Weeps.] He was a kind and tender Maſter to me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray don't grieve Mr. Pillage, you ſhall hold your Place, and every thing elſe which you held under my Uncle—You make me weep to ſee you ſo concern'd. [Weeps.] He liv'd to a good old Age—and we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: We are ſo, Sir, and therefore I muſt beg you to ſign this Leaſe: You'll find Sir Toby has ta'en particular Notice of it in his Will—I could not get it time enough from the Lawyer, or he had ſign'd it before he dy'd. [Gives him a Paper.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: A Leaſe for what?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I rented a Hundred a Year of Sir Toby upon Leaſe, which Leaſe expires at Lady-Day next, and I deſire to renew it for twenty Years—that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Let me ſee. [Looks over the Leaſe.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Matters go ſwimmingly, if nothing intervene. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Very well—Let's ſee what he ſays in his Will about it. [Lays the Leaſe upon the Table, and looks on the Will.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He's very wary, yet I fancy I ſhall be too cunning for him. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ho, here it is—The Farm lying—now in Poſſeſſion of Samuel Pillage—ſuffer him to renew his Leaſe—at the ſame Rent—Very well, Mr. Pillage, I ſee my Uncle does mention it, and I'll perform his Will. Give me the Leaſe— [Col. gives it him, he looks upon it, and lays it upon the Table.] Pray you ſtep to the Door, and call for a Pen and Ink, Mr. Pillage.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have Pen and Ink in my Pocket, Sir, [Pulls out an Inkhorn.] I never go without that.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I think it belongs to your Profeſſion— [He looks upon the Pen, while the Col. changes the Leaſe, and lays down the Contract.] I doubt this is but a ſorry Pen, tho' it may ſerve to write my Name. [Writes.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Little does he think what he ſigns. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: There is your Leaſe, Mr. Pillage, [Gives him the Paper.] Now I muſt deſire you to make what Haſte you can down to Coventry, and take Care of every thing, and I'll ſend down the Undertaker for the Body; do you attend it up, and whatever Charge you are at, I will repay you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You have paid me already, I thank you, Sir. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Will you dine with me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I would rather not, there are ſome of my Neighbours which I met as I came along, who leaves the Town this Afternoon, they told me, and I ſhould be glad of their Company down.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, well, I won't detain you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I don't care how ſoon I am out. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I will give Orders about Mourning.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You will have Cauſe to mourn, when you know your Eſtate imaginary only.

l.hi: You'll find your Hopes and Cares alike are vain,
In Spite of all the Caution you have ta'en,
Fortune rewards the faithful Lover's Pain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
Seven Hundred a Year! I wiſh he had died ſeventeen Years ago;—What a valuable Collection of Rarities might I have had by this time?—I might
have travell'd over all the known Parts of the Globe, and made my own Cloſet Rival the Vatican at Rome.—'Odſo, I have a good Mind to begin my Travels now;—let me ſee,—I am but Sixty! My Father, Grandfather, and Great-Grandfather, reach'd Ninety odd;—I have almoſt forty Years good:—Let me conſider! What will Seven Hundred a Year amount to—in—ay! in thirty Years, I'll ſay but thirty;—Thirty times Seven, is ſeven times Thirty—that is—juſt twenty one thouſand Pound,—'tis a great deal of Money,—I may very well reſerve ſixteen Hundred of it for a Collection of ſuch Rarities, as will make my Name famous to Poſterity;—I wou'd not die like other Mortals, forgotten in a Year or two, as my Uncle will be—No.

l.hi: With Nature's curious Works I'll raiſe my Fame,
That Men, 'till Doom's Day, may repeat my Name.

head.hi: SCENE changes to a Tavern; Freeman and Tradelove over a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Come Mr. Freeman, here's Mynheer Jan, Van Tim, Tam, Tam;—I ſhall never think of that Dutchman's Name.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Mynheer Jan Van Timtamtirelireletta Heer Van Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Ay, Heer Van Fainwell. I never heard ſuch a confounded Name in my Life,—here's his Health I ſay. [Drinks.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Faith, I never expected to have found ſo generous a Thing in a Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Oh, he has nothing of the Hollander in his Temper—except an Antipathy to Monarchy—As ſoon as I told him your Circumſtances, he reply'd, he would not be the Ruin of any Man for the World,—and immediately made this Propoſal himſelf:—Let him take what time he will for the Payment,
ſaid he; or if he'll give me his Ward, I'll forgive him the Debt.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Freeman, I can but thank you,—'Egad you have made a Man of me again; and if ever I lay a Wager more, may I rot in a Goal.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Mr. Tradelove, I was very much concern'd, becauſe I was the Occaſion,—tho' very innocently I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I dare ſwear you was, Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Pleaſe to have a Leſſon of Muſick, or a Song, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: A Song? Ay, with all our Hearts; have you ever a merry one?

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, my Wife and I can give you a merry Dialogue.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: 'Tis very pretty, Faith.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: There's ſomething for you to drink, Friend, go, loſe no Time.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Drawer, and Colonel dreſt for the Dutch Merchant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha, Mynheer Tradelove, Ik ben ſorry voor your Troubles—maer Ik ſal you eaſie maeken, Ik wil degelt niet hebben.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I ſhall for ever acknowledge the Obligation, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But you underſtand upon what Condition Mr. Tradelove, Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ya, de juffrow ſal al te regt ſetten; Mynheer.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Mynheer, you ſhall have my Conſent to marry her freely.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Well then, as I am a Party concern'd between you, Mynheer Jan Van Timtamtirelireletta Heer Van Fainwell ſhall give you a Diſcharge of your Wager under his own Hand,—and you ſhall give him your
Conſent to marry Mrs. Lovely under yours;—that is the way to avoid all manner of Diſputes hereafter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ya, Waeragtig.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſo it is, Mr. Freeman, I'll give it under mine this Minute. [Sits down to write.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And ſo ſal Ik. [Sits down to write.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So, ho, the Houſe, [Enter Drawer.] Bid your Maſter come up—I'll ſee there be Witneſſes enough to the Bargain. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Do you call, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Sackbut, we ſhall want your Hand here.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: There Mynheer, there's my Conſent as amply as you can deſire; but you muſt inſert your own Name, for I know not how to ſpell it; I have left a Blank for it. [Gives the Colonel a Paper.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ya, Ik ſal dat well doen.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Sackbut, you and I will witneſs it. [They write.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Daer Mynheer Tradelove is your Diſcharge. [Gives him a Paper.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to witneſs this Receipt too, Gentlemen. [Freeman and Sackbut put their Hands.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, ay, that we will.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, Mynheer, ye moſt meer doen, ye moſt Myn voorſpraek to de juffrow Syn.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: He means you muſt recommend him to the Lady.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: That I will, and to the reſt of my Brother Guardians.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wat voor den Duyvel heb you meer Guardians?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Only Three, Mynheer.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wat donder heb ye Myn betrocken Mynheer? Had Ik that gewoeten, Ik ſoude eaven met you geweeſt Syn.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: But Mr. Tradelove is the Principal, and he can do a great deal with the reſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And he ſhall uſe his Intereſt I promiſe you Mynheer.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I will ſay all that ever I can think on to recommend you, Mynheer, and if you pleaſe, I'll introduce you to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Well, dat is waer.—Maer ye muſt firſt ſpreken of, Myn, to de juffrow, and to de oudere Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, that's the beſt way,—and then I and the Heer Van Fainwell will meet you there.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I will go this Moment, upon Honour,—Your moſt obedient humble Servant.—My ſpeaking will do you little Good, Minheer, ha, ha; we have bit you, Faith, ha, ha; my Debt's diſcharg'd,—and for the Man, He'as my Conſent—to get her if he can.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this was a Maſter-Piece of Contrivance, Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: He hugs himſelf with his ſuppoſed good Fortune, and little thinks the Luck's of our Side;—but come, purſue the fickle Goddeſs while ſhe's in the Mood.—Now for the Quaker.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That's the hardeſt Task.

l.hi: Of all the Counterfeits perform'd by Man,
A Soldier makes the ſimpleſt Puritan.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: SCENE I. SCENE Prim's Houſe.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Prim, and Mrs. Lovely in Quakers Dreſs, meeting.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: SO, now I like thee, Anne: Art thou not better without thy monſtrous Hoop Coat and Patches!—If Heaven ſhou'd make thee ſo many black Spots upon thy Face, wou'd it not fright thee, Anne?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: If it ſhou'd turn your Inſide outward, and ſhow all the Spots of your Hypocriſy, 'twou'd fright me worſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: My Hypocriſy! I ſcorn thy Words, Anne, I lay no Baits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: If you did, you'd catch no Fiſh.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Well, well, make thy Jeſts;—but I'd have thee to know, Anne, that I cou'd have catch'd as many Fiſh (as thou call'ſt them) in my Time, as ever thou did'ſt with all thy Fool-Traps about thee.—If Admirers be thy Aim, thou wilt have more of them in this Dreſs than thy other.—The Men, take my Word for't, are moſt deſirous to ſee what we are moſt careful to conceal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Is that the Reaſon of your Formality, Mrs. Prim? Truth will out: I ever thought, indeed, there was no more Deſign than Godlineſs in the pinch'd Cap.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Go, thou art corrupted with reading lude Plays, and filthy Romances,—good for nothing but to lead Youth into the High Road of Fornication.—Ah! I wiſh thou art not already too familiar with the wicked Ones.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Too familiar with the wicked Ones! Pray no more of thoſe Freedoms, Madam,—I am familiar with none ſo wicked as your ſelf;—How dare you talk thus to me! you, you, you unworthy Woman you. [Burſts into Tears.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: What, in Tears, Nancy? What have you done to her, Mrs. Prim, to make her weep?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Done to me! I admire I keep my Senſes, among you;—but I will rid my ſelf of your Tyranny, if there be either Law or Juſtice to be had;—I'll force you to give me up my Liberty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Thou haſt more need to weep for thy Sins, Anne,—Yea, for thy manifold Sins.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Don't think that I'll be ſtill the Fool which you have made me,—No, I'll wear what I pleaſe—go when and where I pleaſe,—and keep what Company I think fit, and not what you ſhall direct,—I will.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: For my Part, I do think all this very reaſonable, Mrs. Lovely,—'tis fit you ſhould have your Liberty, and for that very purpoſe I am come.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Periwinkle, and Obediah Prim with a Letter in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I have bought ſome black Stockings of your Husband, Mrs. Prim, but he tells me the Glover's Trade belongs to you, therefore I pray you look me out five or ſix Dozen of mourning Gloves, ſuch as are given at Funerals, and ſend them to my Houſe.—

sp.speaker: Ob. Prim.
sp.p: My Friend Periwinkle has got a good Windfall to Day—ſeven Hundred a Year.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: I wiſh thee Joy of it, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: What, is Sir Toby dead then?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: He is! You'll take care, Mrs. Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Yea, I will, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: This Letter recommendeth a Speaker, 'tis from Aminadab Holdfaſt of Briſtol; peradventure he will be here this Night; therefore Sarah, do thou take care for his Reception.— [Gives her the Letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Prim.
sp.p: I will obey thee.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: What art thou in the Dumps for, Anne?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: We muſt marry her, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Why truly, if we cou'd find a Husband worth having, I ſhou'd be as glad to ſee her married as thou woud'ſt, Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well ſaid, there are but few worth having.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I can recommend you a Man now, that I think you can none of you have an Objection to!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You recommend? Nay, when ever ſhe marries, I'll recommend the Husband.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: What muſt it be, a Whale or a Rinoceros, Mr. Periwinkle, ha, ha, ha? Mr. Tradelove, I have a Bill upon you (gives him a Paper) and have been ſeeking for you all over the Town.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: I'll accept it, Sir Philip, and pay it when due.—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: He ſhall be none of the Fops at your End of the Town, with full Perukes and empty Skulls,—nor yet none of your Trading Gentry, who puzzle the Heralds to find Arms for their Coaches,—No, he ſhall be a Man famous for Travels, Solidity and Curioſity,—one who has ſearch'd into the Profundity of Nature! when Heaven ſhall direct ſuch a one, he ſhall have my Conſent, becauſe it may turn to the Benefit of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: The Benefit of Mankind! What, wou'd you anatomize me?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Madam, he wou'd diſſect you.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Or, pore over you through a Microſcope, to ſee how your Blood circulates from the Crown of your Head to the Sole of your Foot,—ha, ha! but I have a Husband for you, a Man that knows how to improve your Fortune; one that trades to the four Corners of the Globe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: And wou'd ſend me for a Venture perhaps.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: One that will dreſs you in all the Pride of Europe, Aſia, Africa and America—a Dutch Merchant, my Girl.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: A Dutchman! ha, ha, there's a Husband for a fine Lady—Ya Juffrow, will you met myn Slapen—ha, ha; he'll learn you to talk the Language of the Hogs, Madam, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: He'll learn you that one Merchant is of more Service to a Nation, than Fifty Coxcombs.—The Dutch know the Trading Intereſt to be of more Benefit to the State, than the Landed.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: But what is either Intereſt to a Lady?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: 'Tis the Merchant makes the Belle—How would the Ladies ſparkle in the Box without the Merchant? The Indian Diamonds! The French Brocade! The Italian Fan! The Flanders Lace! The fine Dutch Holland!—How would they vent their Scandal over their Tea-tables? and where would you Beaus have Champaigne to toaſt your Miſtreſſes, were it not for the Merchant?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Verily, Neighbour Tradelove, thou doſt waſte thy Breath about nothing—All that thou haſt ſaid tendeth only to debauch Youth, and fill their Heads with the Pride and Luxury of this World—The Merchant is a very great Friend to Satan, and ſendeth as many to his Dominions as the Pope.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Right, I ſay Knowledge makes the Man.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Yea, but not thy kind of Knowledge—it is the Knowledge of Truth—Search thou for the Light within, and not for Bawbles, Friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p:
Ah, ſtudy your Country's Good, Mr. Periwinkle, and not her Inſects.—Rid you of your homebred
Monſters, before you fetch any from abroad—I dare ſwear you have Maggots enough in your own Brain to ſtock all the Virtuoſo's in Europe with Butterflies.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: By my Soul, Miſs Nancy's a Wit.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: That is more than ſhe can ſay by thee, Friend—Look ye, it is in vain to talk, when I meet a Man worthy of her, ſhe ſhall have my leave to marry him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Provided he be one of the Faithful—Was there ever ſuch a Swarm of Caterpillars to blaſt the Hopes of a Woman! [Aſide.] Know this, that you contend in vain: I'll have no Husband of your chuſing, nor ſhall you lord it over me long—I'll try the Power of an Engliſh Senate—Orphans have been redreſs'd, and Wills ſet aſide—and none did ever deſerve their Pity more—Oh Fainwell! where are thy Promiſes to free me from theſe Vermin? Alas! the Task was more difficult than he imagin'd!

l.hi: A harder Task than what the Poets tell

sp.l: Of yore, the fair Andromada befel;

l.hi: She but one Monſter fear'd, I've four to fear,

sp.l: And ſee no Perſeus, no Deliv'rer near.

div.stage: Enter Servant, and whiſpers to Prim.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: One Simon Pure enquireth for thee.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The Woman is mad.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: So are you all, in my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Friend Tradelove, Buſineſs requireth my Preſence.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Oh, I ſhan't trouble you—Pox take him for an unmannerly Dog—However, I have kept my Word with my Dutchman, and will introduce him too for all you.

div.stage: Enter Colonel in a Quaker's Habit.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p:
Friend Pure, thou art welcome; how is it with Friend Holdfaſt, and all Friends in Briſtol? Timothy
Littlewit, John Slenderbrain, and Chriſtopher Keepfaith?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: A goodly Company! [Aſide.] They are all in Health, I thank thee for them.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Friend Holdfaſt writes me Word, that thou cameſt lately from Penſilvania, how do all Friends there—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What the devil ſhall I ſay? I know juſt as much of Penſilvania as I do of Briſtol. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Do they thrive?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yea, Friend, the Bleſſing of their good Works fall upon them.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Prim and Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Sarah, know our Friend Pure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Thou art welcome. [He ſalutes her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Here comes the Sum of all my Wiſhes—How charming ſhe appears, even in that Diſguiſe? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Why doſt thou conſider the Maiden ſo intentively, Friend?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I will tell thee: About four Days ago I ſaw a Viſion—This very Maiden, but in vain Attire, ſtanding on a Precipice; and heard a Voice, which called me by my Name—and bad me put forth my Hand and ſave her from the Pit—I did ſo, and me-thought the Damoſel grew to my Side.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: What can that portend?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: The Damoſel's Converſion—I am perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: That's falſe, I'm ſure— [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Wilt thou uſe the Means, Friend Pure?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Means! what Means? Is ſhe not thy Daughter, and already One of the Faithful?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: No, alas! ſhe's One of the Ungodly.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Pray thee mind what this good Man will ſay unto thee; he will teach thee the Way that thou ſhouldeſt walk, Anne.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: I know my Way without his Inſtructions: I hop'd to have been quiet, when once I had put on your odious Formality here.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then thou weareſt it out of Compulſion, not Choice, Friend?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Thou art in the right of it, Friend—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Art not thou aſhamed to mimick the good Man? Ah! thou art a ſtubborn Girl.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Mind her not; ſhe hurteth not me—If thou wilt leave her alone with me, I will diſcuſs ſome few Points with her, that may, perchance, ſoften her Stubborneſs, and melt her into Compliance.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Content, I pray thee put it home to her—Come, Sarah, let us leave the good Man with her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: [Catching hold of Prim, he breaks looſe and Exit.] What do you mean—to leave me with this old Enthuſiaſtical Canter? Don't think, becauſe I comply'd with your Formality, to impoſe your ridiculous Doctrine upon me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I pray thee, young Woman, moderate thy Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I pray thee, walk after thy Leader, you will but loſe your Labour upon me—Theſe Wretches will certainly make me mad.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am of another Opinion; the Spirit telleth me that I ſhall convert thee, Ann.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis a lying Spirit, don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Say'ſt thou ſo? Why then thou ſhalt convert me, my Angel. [Catching her in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: [Shrieks.] Ah! Monſter hold off, or I'll tear thy Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Huſh! for Heavens ſake—doſt thou not know me? I am Fainwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Fainwell! [Enter old Prim.] Oh I'm undone! Prim here—I wiſh with all my Soul I had been dumb. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: What is the Matter? Why didſt thou ſhriek out, Ann?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Shrick out! I'll ſhriek and ſhriek again, cry Murder, Thieves, or any thing, to drown the Noiſe of that Eternal Babbler, if you leave me with him any longer.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Was that all? Fie, fie, Ann.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No matter, I'll bring down her Stomach, I'll warrant thee—leave us, I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Fare thee well. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My charming lovely Woman. [Embraces her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: What mean'ſt thou by this Diſguiſe, Fainwell?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: To ſet thee free, if thou wilt perform thy Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Make me Miſtreſs of my Fortune, and make thy own Conditions.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This Night ſhall anſwer all thy Wiſhes—See here, I have the Conſent of three of thy Guardians already, and doubt not but Prim ſhall make the fourth. [Prim liſtening.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: I would gladly hear what Argument the good Man uſeth to bend her. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Thy Words give me new Life, methinks.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Thou beſt of Men, Heaven meant to bleſs me ſure, when firſt I ſaw thee.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: He hath mollified her—Oh wonderful Converſion!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! Prim liſtening—No more, my Love, we are obſerv'd; ſeem to be edify'd, and give 'em Hopes that thou wilt turn Quaker, and leave the reſt to me. [Aloud.] I am glad to find that thou art touch'd with what I ſaid unto thee, Ann; another time I will explain the other Article to thee; in the mean while be thou dutiful to our Friend Prim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I ſhall obey thee in every thing.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Oh what a prodigious Change is here! Thou haſt wrought a Miracle, Friend! Ann, how doſt thou like the Doctrine he hath preached?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: So well, that I could talk to him for ever, methinks—I am aſhamed of my former Folly, and ask your Pardon, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Enough, enough that thou art ſorry, he is no Pope, Ann.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Verily thou doſt rejoice me exceedingly, Friend; will it pleaſe thee to walk into the next Room, and refreſh thy ſelf—Come, take the Maiden by the Hand.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: We will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There is another Simon Pure enquireth for thee, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The Devil there is. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Another Simon Pure? I do not know him, is he any Relation of thine?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, Friend, I know him not—Pox take him, I wiſh he were in Penſilvania again, with all my Blood. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: What ſhall I do? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Bring him up.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Humph! then one of us muſt go down, that's certain—Now Impudence aſſiſt me.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: What is thy Will with me, Friend?

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Didſt thou not receive a Letter from Aminadab Holdfaſt of Briſtol, concerning one Simon Pure?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Yea, and Simon Pure is already here, Friend.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And Simon Pure will ſtay here, Friend, if poſſible. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: That's an Untruth, for I am he.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Take thou heed, Friend, what thou doſt ſay; I do affirm that I am Simon Pure.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Thy Name may be Pure, Friend, but not that Pure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Yea that Pure, which my good Friend Aminadab Holdfaſt wrote to my Friend Prim about, the ſame Simon Pure that came from Penſilvania, and ſojourned in Briſtol eleven Days; thou would'ſt not take my
Name from me, would'ſt thou?—till I have done with it. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Thy Name! I am aſtoniſhed.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: At what? at thy own Aſſurance? [Going up to him, S. Pure ſtarts back.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Avant, Sathan; approach me not; I defy thee and all thy Works,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Oh, he'll out cant him—Undone, undone for ever. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hark thee, Friend, thy Sham will not take—Don't exert thy Voice, thou art too well-acquainted with Sathan to ſtart at him, thou wicked Reprobate—What can thy Deſign be here?

div.stage: [Enter Servant, and gives Prim a Letter.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: One of theſe muſt be a Counterfeit, but which I cannot ſay.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What can that Letter be? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Thou muſt be the Devil, Friend, that's certain, for no humane Power can ſtock ſo great a Falſehood.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: This Letter ſayeth that thou art better acquainted with that Prince of Darkneſs, than any here—Read that, I pray thee, Simon. [Gives it the Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Tis Freeman's Hand— [Reads.] There is a Deſign form'd to rob your Houſe this Night, and cut your Throat, and for that purpoſe there is a Man diſguiſed like a Quaker, who is to paſs for one Simon Pure; the Gang whereof I am one, tho' now reſolv'd to rob no more has been at Briſtol, one of them came up in the Coach with the Quaker; whoſe Name he hath taken, and from what he hath gathered from him, formed that Deſign, and did not doubt but he ſhould impoſe ſo far upon you, as to make you turn out the real Simon Pure, and keep him with you. Make the right Uſe of this. Adieu.—Excellent well! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Doſt thou hear this? [To S. Pure.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Yea, but it moveth me not; that, doubtleſs, is the Impoſtor. [Pointing at the Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Ah! thou wicked one—now I conſider thy Face I remember thou didſt come up in the Leathern Convenience with me—thou hadſt a black Bob-Wig
on, and a brown Camblet Coat with Braſs Buttons—canſt thou deny it, ha?

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Yea, I can, and with a ſafe Conſcience too, Friend.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Verily, Friend, thou art the moſt impudent Villain, I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Nay then, I'll have a Fling at him. [Aſide.] I remember the Face of this Fellow at Bath—Ay, this is he that picked my Lady Raffle's Pocket upon the Grove—Don't you remember that the Mob pump'd you, Friend? This is the moſt notorious Rogue—

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: What doth provoke thee to ſeek my Life? Thou wilt not hang me, wilt thou, wrongfully?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: She will do thee no hurt, nor thou ſhalt do me none; therefore get thee about thy Buſineſs Friend, and leave thy wicked Courſe of Life, or thou may'ſt not come off ſo favourably every where.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Go, Friend, I would adviſe thee, and tempt thy Fate no more.

sp.speaker: S. Pu.
sp.p: Yea, I will go, but it ſhall be to thy Confuſion; for I ſhall clear my ſelf: I will return with ſome proofs that ſhall convince thee, Obediah, that thou art highly impoſed upon.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Then there will be no ſtaying for me, that's certain—What the Devil ſhall I do? [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: What monſtrous Works of Iniquity are there in this World, Simon!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yea, the Age is full of Vice—Z'death, I am ſo confounded, I know not what to ſay. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Thou art diſordered, Friend—art thou not well?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
My Spirit is greatly troubled, and ſomething telleth me, that tho' I have wrought a good Work in converting this Maiden, this tender Maiden, yet my Labour will be in vain; for the Evil Spirit fighteth againſt her; and I ſee, yea I ſee with the Eyes of my inward Man, that Sathan will re-buffet her again, whenever I withdraw my ſelf from her; and ſhe will, yea, this very Damoſel will return again to that Abomination
from whence I have retrieved her, as if it were, yea as if it were out of the Jaws of the Fiend—hum—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Good lack! thinkeſt thou ſo?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I muſt ſecond him. [Aſide.] What meaneth this Struggling within me? I feel the Spirit reſiſting the Vanities of this World, but the Fleſh is rebellious, yea the Fleſh—I greatly fear the Fleſh, and the Weakneſs thereof—hum—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: The Maid is inſpir'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Behold, her Light begins to ſhine forth—Excellent Woman! [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: This good Man hath ſpoken Comfort unto me, yea Comfort, I ſay; becauſe the Words which he hath breathed into my outward Ears, are gone thro' and fixed in mine Heart, yea verily in mine Heart, I ſay,—and I feel the Spirit doth love him exceedingly, hum—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: She acts it to the Life. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Prodigious! the Damoſel is filled with the Spirit. Sarah!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: I am greatly rejoic'd to ſee ſuch a Change in our beloved Anne—I came to tell thee that Supper ſtayeth for thee.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am not diſpoſed for thy Food, my Spirit longeth for more delicious Meat;—fain would I redeem this Maiden from the Tribe of Sinners, and break thoſe Cords aſunder wherewith ſhe is bound—Hum—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Something whiſpers in my Ears, methinks,—that I muſt be ſubject to the Will of this good Man, and from him only muſt hope for Conſolation,—Hum—it alſo telleth me that I am a choſen Veſſel to raiſe up Seed to the Faithful, and that thou muſt conſent that we two be one Fleſh according to the Word—hum—

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: What a Revelation is here? This is certainly Part of thy Viſion, Friend, this is the Maiden's growing to thy Side; Ah! with what Willingneſs ſhou'd I give thee my Conſent, could I give thee her Fortune too,—but thou wilt never get the Conſent of the wicked Ones.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wiſh I was as ſure of yours. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: My Soul rejoiceth, yea, it rejoiceth, I ſay, to find the Spirit within thee; for lo, it moveth thee with natural Agitation,—yea, with natural Agitation, I ſay again, and ſtirreth up the Seeds of thy Virgin-Inclination towards this good Man—yea, it ſtirreth, as one may ſay,—yea verily, I ſay it ſtirreth up thy Inclination—yea, as one would ſtir a Pudding.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I ſee, I ſee! the Spirit guiding of thy Hand, good Obediah Prim, and now behold thou art ſigning thy Conſent;—and now I ſee my ſelf within thy Arms, my Friend and Brother, yea, I am become Bone of thy Bone, and Fleſh of thy Fleſh [Embraces him] Hum—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Admirably perform'd [Aſide.] And I will take thee in all ſpiritual Love for an Helpmate, yea, for the Wife of my Boſom,—and now, methinks—I feel a Longing,—yea, a longing, I ſay for the Conſummation of thy Love,—yea, I do long exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: And, verily, verily, my Spirit feeleth the ſame Longing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: The Spirit hath greatly mov'd them both,—Friend Prim, thou muſt conſent, there is no reſiſting of the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p:
Yea, the Light within ſheweth me, that I ſhall fight a good Fight—and wreſtle thro' thoſe reprobate Fiends, thy other Guardians—yea, I perceive the Spirit will hedge thee into the Flock of the Righteous,—Thou art a choſen Lamb—yea a choſen Lamb, and I will not puſh thee back—no, I will not, I ſay—no, thou ſhalt leap-a, and frisk-a, and skip-a, and bound, and bound, I ſay—yea, bound within the Fold of the righteous—yea even within thy Fold, my Brother—
Fetch me the Pen and Ink, Sarah—and my Hand ſhall confeſs its Obedience to the Spirit.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I wiſh it were over.

div.stage: [Enter Mrs. Prim with Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: I tremble leſt this quaking Rogue ſhould return and ſpoil all. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Here Friend, do thou write what the Spirit prompteth, and I will ſign it. [Col. ſits down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Verily, Anne, it greatly rejoiceth me, to ſee thee reformed from that original Wickedneſs wherein I found thee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I do believe thou art, and I thank thee.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: [Reads.] This is to certifie all whom it may concern, that I do freely give up all my Right and Title in Anne Lovely to Simon Pure, and my full Conſent that ſhe ſhall become his Wife, according to the Form of Marriage. Witneſs my Hand.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: That is enough—give me the Pen. [Signs it.

div.stage: Enter Betty running to Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, Madam, here's the Quaking Man again, he has brought a Coachman and two or three more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Ruin'd paſt Redemption! [Aſide to Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, no, one Minute ſooner had ſpoil'd all, but now—here is Company coming, Friend, give me the Paper. [Going up to Prim haſtily.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Here it is, Simon, and I wiſh thee happy with the Maiden.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: 'Tis done, and now Devil do thy worſt.

sp.speaker: Sim. Pu.
sp.p: Look thee, Friend, I have brought theſe People to ſatisfy thee that I am not that Impoſtor which thou dideſt take me for, this is the Man that did drive the Leathern Conveniency, that brought me from Briſtol,—and this is.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Look ye, Friend, to ſave the Court the Trouble of examining Witneſſes—I plead guilty,—ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: How's this? is not thy Name Pure, then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No really, Sir, I only made bold with this Gentleman's Name;—but I here give it up ſafe and found, it has done the Buſineſs which I had occaſion for, and now I intend to wear my own, which ſhall be at his Service upon the ſame Occaſion at any Time: ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sim. Pu.
sp.p: Oh! the Wickedneſs of this Age.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Then you have no farther need of us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, honeſt Man, you may go about your Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: I am ſtruck dumb with thy Impudence, Anne, thou haſt deceived me,—and perchance undone thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Pr.
sp.p: Thou art a diſſembling Baggage, and Shame will overtake thee.

sp.speaker: Sim. Pur.
sp.p: I am grieved to ſee thy Wife ſo much troubled; I will follow and conſole her.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Thy Brother Guardians enquireth for thee; there is another Man with them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Who can that other Man be? [To the Col.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: 'Tis one Freeman, a Friend of mine, whom I order'd to bring the reſt of thy Guardians here.

div.stage: Enter Sir Philip, Tradelove, Periwinkle and Freeman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: [To the Col.] Is all ſafe? did my Letter do you Service?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: All, all's ſafe! ample Service. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Miſs Nancy, how do'ſt do, Child?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Don't call me Miſs, Friend Philip, my Name is Anne, thou knoweſt.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: What, is the Girl metamorphos'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: I wiſh thou wert ſo metamorphos'd. Ah! Philip, throw off that gaudy Attire, and wear the Clothes becoming of thy Age.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: I am aſhamed to ſee theſe Men. [Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: My Age! the Woman is poſſeſs'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, thou art poſſeſs'd rather, Friend.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Hark ye, Mrs. Lovely, one Word with you. [Takes hold of her Hand.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This Maiden is my Wife, thanks to Friend Prim, and thou haſt no Buſineſs with her. [Takes her from him.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: His Wife! hark ye, Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why you have made a very fine Piece of Work of it, Mr. Prim.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Married to a Quaker! thou art a fine Fellow to be left Guardian to an Orphan truly—there's a Husband for a young Lady!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: When I have put on my Beau-Cloaths, Sir Philip, you'll like me better.—

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Thou wilt make a very ſcurvy Beau, Friend.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I believe I can prove it under your Hand, that you thought me a very fine Gentleman in the Park today, about thirty ſix Minutes after Eleven; will you take a Pinch, Sir Philip—out of the fineſt Snuff-Box you ever ſaw. [Offers him Snuff.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I am overjoy'd, faith I am, if thou be'ſt the Gentleman,—I own I did give my Conſent to the Gentleman I brought here to-day,—but if this is he I can't be poſitive.

sp.speaker: Ob. Prim.
sp.p: Canſt thou not—Now I think thou art a fine Fellow to be left Guardian to an Orphan—Thou ſhallow-brain'd Shuttlecock, he may be a Pickpocket for ought thou doſt know.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You would have been two rare Fellows to have been truſted with the ſole Management of her Fortune, would ye not, think ye? But, Mr. Tradelove and my ſelf, ſhall take Care of her Portion.—

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſo we will. Did not you tell me the Dutch Merchant deſired me to meet him here, Mr. Freeman?—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I did ſo, and I am ſure he will be here, if you'll have a little Patience.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What, is Mr. Tradelove impatient? nay then, ik ben gereet voor you, heb ye, Jan van Timtamtirelireletta Heer van Fainwell, vergeeten?

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Oh! pox of the Name! What have you trick'd me too, Mr. Freeman?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Trick'd, Mr. Tradelove! did I not give you Two thouſand Pound for your Conſent fairly? and now do you tell a Gentlemen that he has trick'd you?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: So, ſo, you are a pretty Guardian, faith, ſell your Charge; what, did you look upon her as part of your Stock?

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I am glad thy Knavery is found out however,—I confeſs the Maiden over-reach'd me, and no ſiniſter End at all.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Ay, ay, one thing or another over-reach'd you all—but I'll take care he ſhall never finger a Penny ofher Money, I warrant you,—Over-reach'd quoth'a? Why I might have been over-reach'd too, if I had had no more Wit: I don't know but this very Fellow may be him that was directed to me from Grand Cairo today. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: The very ſame, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Are you ſo, Sir? but your Trick would' not paſs upon me.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, as you ſay, at that Time it did not, that was not my lucky Hour;—but hark ye, Sir, I muſt let you into one Secret—you may keep honeſt John Tradeſcant's Coat on, for your Uncle Sir Toby Periwinkle is not dead,—ſo the Charge of Mourning will be ſaved, ha, ha,—don't you remember Mr. Pillage your Uncle's Steward, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Not dead! I begin to fear I am trick'd too.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Don't you remember the ſigning of a Leaſe, Mr. Periwinkle?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, and what ſignifies that Leaſe, if my Uncle is not dead? ha! I am ſure it was a Leaſe I ſign'd.—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, but it was a Leaſe for Life, Sir, and of this beautiful Tenement, I thank you. [Taking hold of Mrs. Lovely.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Neighbours Fare!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So then, I find you are all trick'd, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am certain I read as plain a Leaſe as ever I read in my Life.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You read a Leaſe I grant you, but you ſign'd this Contract. [Shewing a Paper.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How durſt you put this Trick upon me Mr. Freeman? did not you tell me my Uncle was dying?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And would tell you twice as much to ſerve my Friend, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: What the learned, famous Mr. Periwinkle chous'd too—ha, ha, ha!—I ſhall dye with laughing, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: It had been well if her Father had left her to wiſer Heads than thine and mine, Friend, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: Well, ſince you have outwitted us all, pray you what, and who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Phil.
sp.p: Sir, the Gentleman is a fine Gentleman.—I am glad you have got a Perſon, Madam, who underſtands Dreſs and good Breeding,—I was reſolved ſhe ſhould have a Husband of my chuſing.

sp.speaker: Ob. Pr.
sp.p: I am ſorry the Maiden is fallen into ſuch Hands.

sp.speaker: Trade.
sp.p: A Beau! nay then ſhe is finely help'd up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lov.
sp.p: Why Beaus are great Encouragers of Trade, Sir, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Look ye, Gentlemen,—I am the Perſon who can give the beſt Account of my ſelf, and I muſt beg Sir Philip's Pardon, when I tell him that I have as much Averſion to what he calls Dreſs and Breeding, as I have to the Enemies of my Religion. I have had the Honour to ſerve his Majeſty, and headed a Regiment of the braveſt Fellows that ever puſh'd Bayonet in the Throat of a Frenchman; and, notwithſtanding the Fortune
this Lady brings me, whenever my Country wants my Aid, this Sword and Arm are at her Service.

l.hi: And now, my Fair, if you'll but deign to ſmile,
I meet a Recompence for all my Toil:
Love and Religion ne'er admit Reſtraint,
Force makes many a Sinner, not one Saint;
Still free as Air the active Mind does rove,
And ſearches proper Objects for its Love;
But that once fix'd, 'tis paſt the Power of Art,
To chaſe the dear Ideas from the Heart:
'Tis Liberty of Choice that ſweetens Life,
Makes the glad Husband, and the happy Wiſe.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.l: WHAT new ſtrange Ways our Modern
Beaus deviſe!
What Tryals of Love-Skill to gain the Prize!
The Heathen Gods, who never matter'd Rapes,
Scarce wore ſuch ſtrange Variety of Shapes:
The Devil take their odious barren Skulls,
To court in Form of Snakes and filthy Bulls.
Old Jove once nick'd it, I am told,
In a whole Lapful of true Standard Gold;
How muſt his Godſhip then Fair Danaë warm?
In trucking Ware for Ware there is no Harm.
Well, after all—that Money has a Charm:
But now indeed that ſtale Invention's paſt:
Beſides, you know, that Guineas fall ſo faſt,
Poor Nymph muſt come to Pocket-Piece at laſt.
Old Harry's Face, or good Queen Beſs's Ruff,
Not that I'd take 'em—may do well enough;
No—my ambitious Spirit's far above
Thoſe little Tricks of Mercenary Love.
That Man be mine, who, like the Colonel here,
Can top his Character in every Sphere;
Who can a thouſand Ways employ his Wit,
Out-promiſe Stateſmen, and out-cheat a Cit;
Beyond the Colours of a Trav'ler paint,
And cant, and ogle too—beyond a Saint.
The laſt Diſguiſe moſt pleas'd me, I confeſs,
There's ſomething tempting in the preaching Dreſs;
And pleas'd me more than once a Dame of Note,
Who lov'd her Husband in his Footman's Coat.
To ſee one Eye in wanton Motions play'd,
Th'other to the Heavenly Regions ſtray'd,
As if it for its Fellow's Frailties pray'd.
But yet I hope, for all that I have ſaid,
To find my Spouſe a Man of War in Bed.
